gsx$sttext.$t: On 04/03/20, Gov. Ivey issued an order directing all law enforcement officers to cease enforcing any orders of eviction, with no exceptions provided. On 05/08/20, this order was limited to evictions for non-payment of rent. On 05/21/20, Gov. Ivey issued an order that stated that the moratorium on enforcement would end as of "12:00 AM on June 1."

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Alabama can still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Orders in Alabama did not prevent landlords from filing to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Alabama can still file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Alabama can still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Alabama did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not subject to the CARES Act federal eviction moratorium when filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Alabama were tolled to April 30, 2020

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Whether eviction hearings could be held in Alabama was left to local discretion.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Orders of eviction are not stayed in Alabama.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Alabama.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Alabama was not permitted to enforce an order of eviction against a tenant who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Alabama was not permitted to enforce an orders of eviction for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Alabama was not permitted to enforce non-emergency orders of eviction.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Alabama did not extend past the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Neither Alabama's Public Service Commission nor the governor ordered utility providers not to shut off service. The president of Alabama's PSC has announced that she "is confident" that people who have lost income due to COVID-19 will not have services disconnected.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Utility companies in Alabama were not required to reconnect service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Alabama did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Alabama were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Alabama did not address foreclosures.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Alabama could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Alabama did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance wasn't available in Alabama during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, though it became available to Alabama renters later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Alabama has not guaranteed legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/19/20, the Chief Justice ordered that district court proceedings, including evictions (as clarified in a Presiding Judges' Order dated 03/23/20), be suspended beginning 03/23/20 thru 4/3/20. Judges had discretion to stay any orders of eviction where the tenant was self-quarantining. This suspension was terminated, nunc pro tunc, to 04/24/20; in the same order, the Presiding Judges allowed evictions to take place telephonically, so long as the eviction met the requirements set out in the legislation.  On 04/10/20, the Alaska Legislature passed a bill that suspended the statute the statute governining eviction for non-payment of rent where the tenant is experiencing "financial hardship related to the COVID-19 public health disaster emergency."  The legislation was set to and did expire on 07/1/20.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Alaska can still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Alaska were blocked from filing to evict renters who experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Alaska can still file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Alaska could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Alaska did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not subject to the CARES Act federal eviction moratorium when filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Alaska were tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings were paused in Alaska.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Orders of eviction are not stayed in Alaska. If a tenant is subject to a quarantine order or is self-quarantined pursuant to public health guideline or doctor's recommendation, then a judge has the discretion to stay the eviction.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Alaska.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Alaska could still enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Alaska could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Alaska could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Alaska did not extend past the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Public utility providers in Alaska were able to shut off service to households, with the exception of households where the resident can demonstrate lost income due to the COVID-19 public health disaster. Households who can demonstrate an inability to pay bills due to COVID-19 could have service shut off through November 15, 2020.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Public utility companies in Alaska were required make reasonable efforts to reconnect service to homes where a person is experiencing COVID-19-related financial hardship and the disconnection occurred after March 11th. The emergency legislation did not provide free reconnection for residents whose utility shutoff was disconnected before that date, or who are not able to demonstrate financial hardship.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Alaska did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Alaska were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Foreclosure hearings were paused in Alaska.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Alaska could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Alaska did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance wasn't available in Alaska during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, though it became available to Alaska renters later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Alaska has not guaranteed legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 3/24/20, Gov. Ducey issued an order prohibiting enforcement of an eviction where the tenant could demonstrate an impact from COVID-19 for 120 days. On 07/16/20, the Governor extended the moratorium to expire on 10/31/20. This order required individuals who had already received protection under the moratorium to notify the landlord in writing of their continuing hardship and proof of their submission of an application for rental assistance.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Arizona can still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Orders in Arizona did not prevent landlords from filing to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Arizona can still file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Arizona could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Arizona required landlords to certify that a dwelling is not subject to the CARES Act federal eviction moratorium when filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Arizona were tolled to August 1, 2020.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could still be held in Arizona.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Orders of eviction are not stayed in Arizona.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Arizona.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Arizona was not permitted to enforce an order of eviction against a tenant who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic. This protection ended on November 1, 2020.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Arizona could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic, except in some COVID-19-related cases.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Arizona could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Arizona did not extend past the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: The Arizona Corporation Commission did not issue an order directing utilities to halt disconnections.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: The Arizona Corporation Commission did not not issue an order requiring utilities to reconnect service to residents.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Arizona did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Arizona were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Arizona did not address foreclosures.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Arizona could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Arizona did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance wasn't available in Arizona during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, though it became available to Arizona renters later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Arizona has not guaranteed legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Arkansas could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Arkansas required landlords to certify that a dwelling is not subject to the CARES Act federal eviction moratorium when filing to evict a tenant, but only until July 25, 2020.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Arkansas were not tolled.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Arkansas.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Arkansas could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Arkansas could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Arkansas did not extend past the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Utility providers under the jurisdiction of Arkansas's Public Service Commission were prohibited from disconnecting service to residents for reason of nonpayment of bills for the duration of the emergency declaration in Arkansas.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Utility providers under the jurisdiction of Arkansas's Public Service Commission were required to waive fees associated with reconnecting utilities for the duration of the emergency declaration in Arkansas.

content.$t: stname: California, intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 17,035,151, evstat2: 3,160,971, intstat3: 1,636,391, intstat4: 5,880,000, intstat5: 0, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 0, intstat7: 0, stars: 1.33, intinitiationscore: 0.3, intcourtscore: 0.3, intenfscore: 0, intsupportscore: 0, inttenscore: 0.5, sttext: On 03/27/20, Gov. Newsom issued an order that extended the summons period by 60 day and prohibited eviction enforcement against tenants who were being evicted for non-payment of rent and who could document an impact from COVID-19 (including layoff, wage loss; not able to work due to COVID-19 illness in self or household member or lack of childcare due to school closure). This order was in effect through 05/31/20. On 04/04/20, effective 04/06/20, the California Judicial Council announced several emergency rules, one of which prohibited courts from issuing summonses, defaults, or default judgments in any unlawful detainer case unless necessary to protect health and safety. This rule also required courts to set trial dates in open cases no earlier than 60 days from the landlords request for trial, unless an earlier trial date was found necessary to protect health and safety. This rule remained in effect thru 9/1/20, with a replacement from Judicial Council in an order memorandum issued on 08/13/20. On 08/31/20, The California legislature passed emergency legislation that prohibited issuance of a summons in an unlawful detainer action for non-payment of rent until 10/5/20. From 10/05/20 to 01/31/20, the legislation provides that the landlord must have provided the tenant a 15-day notice prior to filing for eviction that the tenant may be eligible for protections if they've suffered an impact from COVID-19. If a tenant's rental debt accrued between 03/01/20-08/31/20, then return of a signed notice prohibits the landlord from filing for eviction on the basis of that debt. If a tenant's rental debt accrues between 09/01/20 and 01/31/21, the return of a signed notice prohibits the landlord from filing for eviction so long as the tenant pays at least 25% of the total rental debt for this period by 1/31/2021. On 1/29/21, the governor signed legislation that states, beginning 7/1/21, tenants who have not paid at least 25% of the total rental debt accrued from 9/1/20 and 6/30/21 due to the COVID-19 pandemic can be evicted. The 25% payment requirement can take the form of a 25% of monthly rent payment between September 1, 2020 through June 30th, 2021, or a lump sum payment by June 30, 2021 that brings the total paid to 25 percent of what is due over the period covered., plcstandoutbool: 1, until: June 30, 2021 (end of study period), intwtxp: exec order, plcnoticebool: 0, plcnoticetext: Landlords in California could still give notice of eviction to tenants., plccofilbool: 1, plccofiltext: A law in California required that landlords deliver a form asking about financial distress due to COVID-19 to tenants who are behind on rent. Tenants who fill out the form and assert that they have decreased income or increased expenses due to COVID-19 cannot be evicted. This should mean that landlords are not able to file to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic., intcofillink: http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billNavClient.xhtml?bill_id=201920200AB3088, plcnonpbool: 0, plcnonptext: Landlords in California could still file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent, if the tenant did not return a signed COVID-19 financial impact declaration., intplcnonplink: http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billNavClient.xhtml?bill_id=201920200AB3088, plcnofilbool: 0, plcnofiltext: Landlords in California could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons., intplcnofillink: https://jcc.legistar.com/View.ashx?M=F&ID=8234474&GUID=79611543-6A40-465C-8B8B-D324F5CAE349, plccaresbool: 0, plccarestext: Courts in California did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not subject to the CARES Act federal eviction moratorium when filing to evict a tenant., intcareslink: No relevant order, plctldbool: 0, plctldtext: Court deadlines in California were not tolled for the full duration of the moratorium., plcnohearbool: 0, plcnoheartext: Eviction hearings were not blocked in California during the full duration of the moratorium., plcnonewbool: 0, plcnonewtext: Eviction orders were not stayed in California., plcsealbool: 1, plcsealtext: California courts seal eviction case records if the action is denied, the case dismissed, or parties stipulate to sealing. California has passed an additional law sealing more records for cases that started during the pandemic., plccovenfbool: 0, plccovenftext: Orders in California did not expressly bar law enforcement from enforcing an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic. California's Public Utilities Commission has also ordered that energy, water, sewer, and communications companies under CPUC jursidiction halt disconnections for nonpayment., plcfrrcbool: 0, plcfrrctext: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in California are required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee., intplcfrrclink: https://docs.cpuc.ca.gov/PublishedDocs/Published/G000/M336/K601/336601411.PDF, plcarsbool: 0, plcarstext: Orders in California did not give tenants a formal grace period to repay back rent that accrues during the pandemic. However, legislation in California created a grace period to pay back 75% of rent if tenants paid the 25% of rental arrears that accrued during the pandemic before the end of the eviction moratorium., intplcarslink: https://www.gov.ca.gov/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/3.27.20-EO-N-37-20.pdf, plcnorepbool: 0, plcnoreptext: Landlords in California were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies., intnoreplink: https://covid19.ca.gov/get-financial-help/, plcnofcbool: 0, plcnofctext: The Judicial Council order that suspended foreclosure proceedings in California, Emergency Rule 2, expired before the legislative moratorium., plcnofclink: https://jcc.legistar.com/View.ashx?M=F&ID=8234474&GUID=79611543-6A40-465C-8B8B-D324F5CAE349, plclatfbool: 0, plclatftext: Landlords in California could still charge late fees., plcraisebool: 0, plcraisetext: Orders in California did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic., plcdebtbool: 1, plcdebttext: Tenants and landlords in California could apply for COVID-19 Rent Relief., intdebtlink: https://housing.ca.gov/covid_rr/program_overview.html#renter, plccgbool: 0, plccgtext: California did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction. San Francisco tenants have a right to counsel in eviction proceedings and Los Angeles has an eviction defense fund pilot program. Santa Monica has announced an intention to enact a right to counsel.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/27/20, Gov. Newsom issued an order that extended the summons period by 60 day and prohibited eviction enforcement against tenants who were being evicted for non-payment of rent and who could document an impact from COVID-19 (including layoff, wage loss; not able to work due to COVID-19 illness in self or household member or lack of childcare due to school closure). This order was in effect through 05/31/20. On 04/04/20, effective 04/06/20, the California Judicial Council announced several emergency rules, one of which prohibited courts from issuing summonses, defaults, or default judgments in any unlawful detainer case unless necessary to protect health and safety. This rule also required courts to set trial dates in open cases no earlier than 60 days from the landlords request for trial, unless an earlier trial date was found necessary to protect health and safety. This rule remained in effect thru 9/1/20, with a replacement from Judicial Council in an order memorandum issued on 08/13/20. On 08/31/20, The California legislature passed emergency legislation that prohibited issuance of a summons in an unlawful detainer action for non-payment of rent until 10/5/20. From 10/05/20 to 01/31/20, the legislation provides that the landlord must have provided the tenant a 15-day notice prior to filing for eviction that the tenant may be eligible for protections if they've suffered an impact from COVID-19. If a tenant's rental debt accrued between 03/01/20-08/31/20, then return of a signed notice prohibits the landlord from filing for eviction on the basis of that debt. If a tenant's rental debt accrues between 09/01/20 and 01/31/21, the return of a signed notice prohibits the landlord from filing for eviction so long as the tenant pays at least 25% of the total rental debt for this period by 1/31/2021. On 1/29/21, the governor signed legislation that states, beginning 7/1/21, tenants who have not paid at least 25% of the total rental debt accrued from 9/1/20 and 6/30/21 due to the COVID-19 pandemic can be evicted. The 25% payment requirement can take the form of a 25% of monthly rent payment between September 1, 2020 through June 30th, 2021, or a lump sum payment by June 30, 2021 that brings the total paid to 25 percent of what is due over the period covered.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in California could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: A law in California required that landlords deliver a form asking about financial distress due to COVID-19 to tenants who are behind on rent. Tenants who fill out the form and assert that they have decreased income or increased expenses due to COVID-19 cannot be evicted. This should mean that landlords are not able to file to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in California could still file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent, if the tenant did not return a signed COVID-19 financial impact declaration.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in California could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in California did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not subject to the CARES Act federal eviction moratorium when filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in California were not tolled for the full duration of the moratorium.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings were not blocked in California during the full duration of the moratorium.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in California.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: California courts seal eviction case records if the action is denied, the case dismissed, or parties stipulate to sealing. California has passed an additional law sealing more records for cases that started during the pandemic.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Orders in California did not expressly bar law enforcement from enforcing an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic. However, no orders should be issued for these tenants.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in California could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in California could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders, except for tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to COVID-19.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Legislation in California was not tied to the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: California's governor signed an executive order suspending disconnections of water service. California's Public Utilities Commission has also ordered that energy, water, sewer, and communications companies under CPUC jursidiction halt disconnections for nonpayment.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in California are required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in California did not give tenants a formal grace period to repay back rent that accrues during the pandemic. However, legislation in California created a grace period to pay back 75% of rent if tenants paid the 25% of rental arrears that accrued during the pandemic before the end of the eviction moratorium.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in California were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: The Judicial Council order that suspended foreclosure proceedings in California, Emergency Rule 2, expired before the legislative moratorium.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in California could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in California did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Tenants and landlords in California could apply for COVID-19 Rent Relief.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: California did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction. San Francisco tenants have a right to counsel in eviction proceedings and Los Angeles has an eviction defense fund pilot program. Santa Monica has announced an intention to enact a right to counsel.

content.$t: stname: Colorado, intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 1,789,202, evstat2: 280,375, intstat3: 185,416, intstat4: 742,242, intstat5: 0, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 0, intstat7: 0, stars: 3.38, intinitiationscore: 1, intcourtscore: 0, intenfscore: 1, intsupportscore: 0, inttenscore: 0.625, sttext: On 04/30/20, Gov. Polis issued an order that prohibited landlords from filing or initiating eviction becase of a tenant's default of any contractual obligation. The order also prohibited the removal/exclusion of a tenant and the execution or enforcement of a writ of possession, except where the tenant posed an imminent and serious threat to another individual or significant damage to property. On 05/29/20, Gov. Polis limited these protections to tenants who had been unable to pay rent due to an financial hardship due to COVID-19. This order also encourages jurisdictions to lift restrictions on household occupancy and hotel stay limits. The protections of the 05/29 order were set to and did expire 15 days later, on 06/13/20. On 10/15/20, Gov. Polis required that landlords provide tenants with 30 days notice on any rent default that occurred on or after 3/10/20 before filing an eviction. The order also required a landlord serve a tenant with a CDC declaration form before filing for eviction. On 10/21/20, Gov. Polis reinstated an eviction moratorium for those who could prove COVID-19 impact (using CDC declaration language) for 30 days. That order was extended on 11/19/20. On 12/18/20, the order extended the definition of COVID-19 hardship to a person who "at any time after 3/10/20" met the criteria. The moratorium expired on 12/31/20., plcstandoutbool: 1, until: May 29, 2020, intwtxp: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1EcHGKlh14sJ3V3xwzQbdqHllj43nBzTH/view, plcnoticebool: 1, plcnoticetext: Landlords in Colorado could not give notice of eviction to tenants., plccofilbool: 1, plccofiltext: Landlords in Colorado were not able to file to evict renters who had experienced financial distress due to the pandemic., plcnonpbool: 1, plcnonptext: Landlords in Colorado were not able to file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent., plcnofilbool: 1, plcnofiltext: Landlords in Colorado were not able to file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons., intplcnofillink: CO_Governor_ExecOrder_D2020101_061320, plccaresbool: 0, plccarestext: Orders in Colorado did not require landlords to certify gsx$sttext.$t: On 04/30/20, Gov. Polis issued an order that prohibited landlords from filing or initiating eviction becase of a tenant's default of any contractual obligation. The order also prohibited the removal/exclusion of a tenant and the execution or enforcement of a writ of possession, except where the tenant posed an imminent and serious threat to another individual or significant damage to property. On 05/29/20, Gov. Polis limited these protections to tenants who had been unable to pay rent due to an financial hardship due to COVID-19. This order also encourages jurisdictions to lift restrictions on household occupancy and hotel stay limits. The protections of the 05/29 order were set to and did expire 15 days later, on 06/13/20. On 10/15/20, Gov. Polis required that landlords provide tenants with 30 days notice on any rent default that occurred on or after 3/10/20 before filing an eviction. The order also required a landlord serve a tenant with a CDC declaration form before filing for eviction. On 10/21/20, Gov. Polis reinstated an eviction moratorium for those who could prove COVID-19 impact (using CDC declaration language) for 30 days. That order was extended on 11/19/20. On 12/18/20, the order extended the definition of COVID-19 hardship to a person who "at any time after 3/10/20" met the criteria. The moratorium expired on 12/31/20.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Colorado could not give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Colorado were not able to file to evict renters who had experienced financial distress due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Colorado were not able to file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Colorado were not able to file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Orders in Colorado did not require landlords to certify that properties were not "covered" under the CARES Act eviction moratorium.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Colorado were not tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings were not paused in Colorado.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction judgments were not stayed in Colorado, however, law enforcement officers were not permitted to carry out eviction orders.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction cases were not sealed at the time in Colorado.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement officers in Colorado were prohibited from enforcing an order to remove a tenant who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement officers in Colorado were prohibited from enforcing an order to remove a tenant for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement officers in Colorado were prohibited from enforcing an order to remove a tenant for a non-emergency reason.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Current orders in Colorado do not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Utilities in Colorado were prohibited from disconnecting service due to nonpayment.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Colorado's governor signed an executive order directing the Public Utilities Commission to work with utilities to reconnect service to residents with no fees. All utilities companies in Colorado are compliant with the order.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Current orders in Colorado don't give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Colorado are not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Current orders in Colorado have not expressly halted foreclosure hearings.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Colorado were banned from charging late or convenience fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Current orders in Colorado do not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Colorado made $3 million from the Disaster Emergency Fund available for rental and mortgage assistance.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Colorado has not guaranteed legal counsel to tenants who face eviction, but the legislature has allocated $350,000 to the legal defense fund to assist tenants facing eviction.

content.$t: stname: Connecticut, intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 1,057,962, evstat2: 203,549, intstat3: 122,110, intstat4: 460,240, intstat5: 0, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 0, intstat7: 0, stars: 3.78, intinitiationscore: 1, intcourtscore: 0.7, intenfscore: 1, intsupportscore: 0.75, inttenscore: 0.125, sttext: On 03/12/20, the CT Supreme Court announced that, effective 03/16/20, CT courts would be hearing only emergency matters, which did not include eviction cases. On 03/19/20, the high court announced that all civil trials and hearings would be cancelled indefinitely and there would be an immediate stay of all issued executions on eviction through 5/1/20. The stay on executions was extended several times until 09/03/20, when it was narrowed to apply only to eviction actions for non-payment of rent that accrued after 02/29/20. On 09/14/20, the courts began scheduling hearings on execution requests. On 04/10/20, Gov. Lamont issued an order that prohibited landlords from serving notice or process (and thus also prohibiting filing) until 07/01/20, with the exception of cases of serious nuisance. This order also granted tenants a two month grace period to pay April and May rent. The prohibition on notice has been extended several times [06/29/20; 08/31/20]. On 09/30/20, Gov. Lamont added an exception to allow for notice where there was "serious nonpayment of rent," or "a rent arrearage equal to or greater than six months worth of rent due on or after March 1, 2020."  On 12/23/20, the Governor announced the prohibition on notice would remain in effect until 02/09/21 and modified Section 47a-42 of the Connecticut General Statutes to additionally provide: No state marshal charged with executing upon any judgment of eviction pursuant to Section 47a-26, 47a-26a, 47a-26b or 47a26d of the Connecticut General Statutes for the recovery of possession or occupancy of residential property shall execute upon any such judgment before January 2, 2021. On 02/08/21, Gov. Lamont extended the prohibition on notice. On 4/19/21 and on 05/20/21, the Governor extended his earlier orders., plcstandoutbool: 1, until: May 31, 2020, intwtxp: On 03/19/20, the high court announced that all civil trials and hearings would be cancelled indefinitely and there would be an immediate stay of all issued executions on eviction through 5/1/20. The stay on executions was extended several times until 09/03/20, when it was narrowed to apply only to eviction actions for non-payment of rent that accrued after 02/29/20. On 09/14/20, the courts began scheduling hearings on execution requests. On 04/10/20, Gov. Lamont issued an order that prohibited landlords from serving notice or process (and thus also prohibiting filing) until 07/01/20, with the exception of cases of serious nuisance. This order also granted tenants a two month grace period to pay April and May rent. The prohibition on notice has been extended several times [06/29/20; 08/31/20]. On 09/30/20, Gov. Lamont added an exception to allow for notice where there was "serious nonpayment of rent," or "a rent arrearage equal to or greater than six months worth of rent due on or after March 1, 2020."  On 12/23/20, the Governor announced the prohibition on notice would remain in effect until 02/09/21 and modified Section 47a-42 of the Connecticut General Statutes to additionally provide: No state marshal charged with executing upon any judgment of eviction pursuant to Section 47a-26, 47a-26a, 47a-26b or 47a26d of the Connecticut General Statutes for the recovery of possession or occupancy of residential property shall execute upon any such judgment before January 2, 2021. On 02/08/21, Gov. Lamont extended the prohibition on notice. On 4/19/21 and on 05/20/21, the Governor extended his earlier orders.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Connecticut could not give notices of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Connecticut could not file to evict tenants who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Connecticut could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Connecticut could not file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Landlords in Connecticut were not required to certify properties were not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium before filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Connecticut were tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could not be heard in Connecticut.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction judgments in Connecticut were stayed.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records are not sealed in Connecticut.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement officers in Connecticut were prohibited from enforcing an order to remove a tenant who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement officers in Connecticut were prohibited from enforcing an order to remove a tenant for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement officers in Connecticut were prohibited from enforcing an order to remove a tenant for a non-emergency reason.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Connecticut did not extend past the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Connecticut's Public Utilities Regulatory Authority ordered that utility companies suspend disconnections of service for nonpayment.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: It is not clear if utilities in Connecticut were required to reconnect service for customers who had service suspended due to nonpayment of bills.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Executive orders in Connecticut gave tenants a grace period to pay late rent.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Executive orders in Connecticut prohibited landlords from reporting late rent payments to credit bureaus.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Foreclosure judgments were suspended in Connecticut.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Connecticut could not charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Connecticut did not prohibit landlords from raising rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: At the time of Connecticut's strongest moratorium, rental assistance was not available to all qualifying tenants. Rental assistance later became available through UniteCT.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Connecticut has not guaranteed legal counsel to tenants who face eviction. Legislation that would guarantee a right to counsel in eviction proceedings is pending.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 3/15/20, the Delaware Justice of the Peace Court issued an order rescheduling all landlord-tenant proceedings and all ordered evictions scheduled from 03/17-04/26 to a date after 05/01. On 04/23/20, the Justice of the Peace court rescheduled all landlord-tenant proceedings through 05/14 to a date not earlier than 06/01/20, and on 06/03/20, the Court continued its 04/23 order until further order of the court. On 03/24/20, Gov. Carney issued an order prohibiting bringing of cases, execution of writs of possession, and also extending deadlines in pending cases.  On 06/30/20, the Governor lifted the moratorium as of 07/01/20. The prohibition on filing was stayed to allow the Justice of the Peace to determine whether ADR or mediation would benefit parties. On 07/08/20, the Justice of the Peace Court announced, effective 07/01/20, that proceedings would resume with "trial dates based upon the order in which [actions] were received prior to the health emergency and upon the resumption of filings on July 1, 2020."

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Delaware could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Delaware could not file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: At the time, landlords in Delaware were not required to certify properties were not required by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict the tenant. However, eviction filings were not permitted at the time.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Delaware were tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could not be heard in Delaware, except limited emergency cases.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Orders of eviction in Delaware were stayed to May 15, 2020.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Delaware.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement officers in Delaware were prohibited from enforcing an order to remove a tenant who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement officers in Delaware were prohibited from enforcing an order to remove a tenant for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement officers in Delaware were prohibited from enforcing an order to remove a tenant for a non-emergency reason.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: The executive order in Delaware delayed court actions and the enforcement of eviction orders that were filed before the pandemic started until at least 31 days after the end of the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Delaware has prohibited the disconnection of electric, natural gas, telegraph, telephone, water, wastewater, cable television, or internet service for nonpayment for the duration of the pandemic.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders do not make it clear if utility companies in Delaware are required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Delaware did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Delaware did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

DeSantis issued an order suspending any eviction cause of action for non-payment of rent due to the COVID-19 emergency. On 07/29/20, after several extensions, Gov. DeSantis modified the 04/02 order to suspend statutes providing for the "final action at the conclusion of an eviction proceeding" when the proceeding was for non-payment of rent and the tenant has been adversely affected by COVID-19 (including loss of employment, diminished wages or business income, or other monetary loss realized during the Florida State of Emergency directly impacting the ability of a residential tenant to make rent payments).  After one further extension, that order expired on 10/01/20. On 03/17/20, the Florida Supreme Court stated in an order that, "Given the exigencies of the public health emergency, the requirement in Florida Rule of Civil Procedure 1.580(a) for the clerk to issue a writ of possession forthwith shall be suspended through the close of business on Friday, April 17, 2020, or as provided by subsequent order." gsx$sttext.$t: On 04/02/20, Gov. DeSantis issued an order suspending any eviction cause of action for non-payment of rent due to the COVID-19 emergency. On 07/29/20, after several extensions, Gov. DeSantis modified the 04/02 order to suspend statutes providing for the "final action at the conclusion of an eviction proceeding" when the proceeding was for non-payment of rent and the tenant has been adversely affected by COVID-19 (including loss of employment, diminished wages or business income, or other monetary loss realized during the Florida State of Emergency directly impacting the ability of a residential tenant to make rent payments).  After one further extension, that order expired on 10/01/20. On 03/17/20, the Florida Supreme Court stated in an order that, "Given the exigencies of the public health emergency, the requirement in Florida Rule of Civil Procedure 1.580(a) for the clerk to issue a writ of possession forthwith shall be suspended through the close of business on Friday, April 17, 2020, or as provided by subsequent order." This suspension remained in effect through 06/30/20.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Florida could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Florida were prevented from filing to evict tenants who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Florida could still file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Florida could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Orders in Florida did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Florida were only tolled for cases related to COVID-19 hardship.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could be held in Florida.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Florida.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Florida.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Florida could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Florida could enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement officers in Florida could enforce an order of eviction for a non-emergency reason.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: The order in Florida did not extend past the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Florida's governor and Public Service Commission did not take action to require utilities to suspend service shutoffs during the pandemic.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Florida's governor and Public Service Commission did not take action to require utilities to reconnect utilities service without fees during the pandemic.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Florida did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Florida were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: New foreclosure actions were banned in Florida.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Florida could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders orders in Florida did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Florida allocated $120 million of CARES Act funding for rental assistance subsidies for households who experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Florida did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: Georgia did not implement any statewide eviction moratorium during the pandemic. Rental assistance was available to renters in Georgia at some points during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Georgia could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Orders in Georgia did not prevent landlords from filing to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Georgia could still file to evict tenants for nonpayment.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Georgia could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Georgia did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not subject to the CARES Act federal eviction moratorium when filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Georgia were tolled until July 14, 2020, however, the state did not implement an eviction moratorium.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could still be held in Georgia.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Georgia.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Georgia.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Georgia could still enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Georgia could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Georgia could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Georgia did not extend past the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Georgia's governor and Public Service Commission did not action to require utilities to suspend service shutoffs during the pandemic. Many utilities in Georgia voluntarily suspended shutoffs.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Georgia's governor and Public Service Commission did not take action to require utilities to reconnect utilities service without fees during the pandemic.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Georgia did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Georgia were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Georgia did not address foreclosures.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Georgia could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Georgia did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Georgia did not institute an eviction moratorium at any point during the study period. Rental assistance, including from the federal government, was available at some points during the study period.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Georgia has not guaranteed legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/16/20, the HI Supreme Court issued an order, effective 03/17/20, continuing civil trials, including landlord tenant matters until 04/30/20. On 04/27/20, the high court granted the chief judges of each circuit discretion to designate matters that could be held using remote technology.  On 03/17/20, the Public Safety Division announced it would cease enforcement of evictions, no end date was given for the cessation. On 04/16/20, Gov. Ige issued an order, effective 04/17/20, suspending the statutes allowing for the filing of eviction for non-payment of rent and fees and holdovers. On 12/16/20, Gov. Ige extended the moratorium until 02/14/21. On 02/12/21, the Governor extended the moratorium through 04/13/21. On 04/09/21, the Governor extended the moratorium through 06/08/21. On 06/07/21, Gov. Ige extended the moratorium through 08/06/21.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Hawaii were barred from giving notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Hawaii could not file to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Hawaii could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Hawaii could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Hawaii did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not subject to the CARES Act federal eviction moratorium when filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Hawaii were not tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: While a statewide order explicitly blocking eviction hearings in Hawaii expired in April 2020, the filings ban in Hawaii and Circuit Court orders banning eviction proceedings make it unlikely that eviction hearings occured during Hawaii's eviction moratorium.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Hawaii.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Hawaii.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Hawaii did not enforce orders to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Hawaii did not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Hawaii did not enforce eviction orders issued for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Current orders in Hawaii did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Hawaii's Public Utilities Commission ordered that all jurisdictional electric, gas, telecommunications, water, and wastewater public utilities suspend disconnections of service for the duration of the governor's emergency proclamation or further order by the Commission.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Hawaii's Public Utilities Commission ordered that all regulations that prevent reconnection of service be waived during the pandemic.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Hawaii did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Hawaii were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Hawaii did not directly address foreclosure.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Hawaii could charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Hawaii did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: More than $150 million was made available in Hawaii for rental assistance, in all counties in Hawaii, during the state's eviction moratorium.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Hawaii did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/13/20, the ID Supreme Court issued an order, effective 03/16/20, that continued all eviction "cases" except for emergency matters or where required by statute or court rule to 04/10/20. On 03/26/20, the Court extended the hearing ban but allowed evictions that involved production, delivery, or use of a controlled substance on the property. The high court issued the final extension of this order on 04/21/20, setting an end date after 04/30/20.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Idaho's governor and Public Utilities Commission did not take action to require utilities to reconnect utilities service without fees during the pandemic.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Idaho did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Idaho did not address foreclosures.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Idaho could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Idaho did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

content.$t: stname: Illinois, intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 3,920,658, evstat2: 623,558, intstat3: 408,090, intstat4: 1,641,003, intstat5: 0, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 0, intstat7: 0, stars: 3.08, intinitiationscore: 0.8, intcourtscore: 0.3, intenfscore: 1, intsupportscore: 0, inttenscore: 0.5, sttext: On 03/20/20, Gov. Pritzker issued an order, effective 03/21/20 at 5 PM, prohibiting enforcement of residential evictions for the duration of the disaster proclamation. On 4/23/20, the Governor added a prohibition on the commencement (notice and filing pursuant to cited statute) of residential evictions unless the tenant posed a direct threat to the health and safety of other tenants, an immediate and severe risk to property, or a violation of any applicable building code, health ordinance (The 04/23/20 order did not supersede the 03/20/20 order). On 04/30/20, the prohibition on enforcement and commencement of residential evictions were combined into one order and extended through 05/29/20. The governor continued to reissue and extend the prohibition on enforcement and commencement with subsequent executive orders. On 11/13/20, the Governor limited the commencement moratorium to those "covered persons" who provided landlords with a declaration that they had been impacted by COVID-19 ("covered persons" are defined with the some of the language as the CDC moratorium but also require nonpayment due to COVID-19 hardship); the ban on enforcement of residential evictions continued unchanged. By limiting protections to "covered persons," the 11/13/20 order excluded both "no cause" terminations and terminations for lease violations that do not fall within the emergency exception. On 12/11/20, the Governor amended and revised the order to clarify that a tenant who does not owe rent is not required to provide a declaration, and landlords cannot commence an eviction against a tenant who does not owe rent unless they pose a direct threat to the health and safety of other tenants or an immediate and severe risk to property . On 01/08/21, this order was reissued and extended through 02/06/21. On 02/05/21, Gov. Pritzker extended the order through 03/06/21. On 03/05/21, the Governor reissued the order and prohibited continuation of eviction actions against covered persons. On 05/28/21, Gov. Pritzker extended the moratorium through 06/26/21., plcstandoutbool: 1, until: November 12, 2020, intwtxp: https://www2.illinois.gov/Pages/Executive-Orders/ExecutiveOrder2021-01.aspx, plcnoticebool: gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/20/20, Gov. Pritzker issued an order, effective 03/21/20 at 5 PM, prohibiting enforcement of residential evictions for the duration of the disaster proclamation. On 4/23/20, the Governor added a prohibition on the commencement (notice and filing pursuant to cited statute) of residential evictions unless the tenant posed a direct threat to the health and safety of other tenants, an immediate and severe risk to property, or a violation of any applicable building code, health ordinance (The 04/23/20 order did not supersede the 03/20/20 order). On 04/30/20, the prohibition on enforcement and commencement of residential evictions were combined into one order and extended through 05/29/20. The governor continued to reissue and extend the prohibition on enforcement and commencement with subsequent executive orders. On 11/13/20, the Governor limited the commencement moratorium to those "covered persons" who provided landlords with a declaration that they had been impacted by COVID-19 ("covered persons" are defined with the some of the language as the CDC moratorium but also require nonpayment due to COVID-19 hardship); the ban on enforcement of residential evictions continued unchanged. By limiting protections to "covered persons," the 11/13/20 order excluded both "no cause" terminations and terminations for lease violations that do not fall within the emergency exception. On 12/11/20, the Governor amended and revised the order to clarify that a tenant who does not owe rent is not required to provide a declaration, and landlords cannot commence an eviction against a tenant who does not owe rent unless they pose a direct threat to the health and safety of other tenants or an immediate and severe risk to property . On 01/08/21, this order was reissued and extended through 02/06/21. On 02/05/21, Gov. Pritzker extended the order through 03/06/21. On 03/05/21, the Governor reissued the order and prohibited continuation of eviction actions against covered persons. On 05/28/21, Gov. Pritzker extended the moratorium through 06/26/21.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Illinois could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Illinois were not able to evict tenants who experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Illinois could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Illinois could not file to evict tenant for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Landlords in Illinois were required to certify that a dwelling was not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Illinois were not tolled at the time of this moratorium.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Orders in Illinois did not block courts from hearing eviction cases during the crisis.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Illinois.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Many eviction cases in Illinois, including all cases from the pandemic that were filed due to financial hardship, will be sealed under a new law.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Illinois could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Illinois could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Illinois could not enforce eviction orders issued for non-emergency reasons before the governor's disaster proclamation and until the proclamation ends.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Illinois did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: The Illinois Commerce Commission required that utilities suspend disconnections of electric, natural gas, water, and wastewater service during the pandemic.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Utility companies in Illinois were required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Current orders in Illinois did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Illinois were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Illinois did not address foreclosures.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Illinois could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Illinois did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Illinois allocated hundreds of millions of dollars for rental and mortgage assistance, including during this eviction moratorium.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Illinois did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/19/20, Gov. Holcomb issued an order prohibiting the "initiation" of evictions and suspended the statutes governing such proceedings from the date of the order. On 03/25/20, the IN Supreme Court stated that IN courts should continue to accept eviction filings, as required by the IN Constitution; local courts were given judicial discretion on the decision to stay proceedings. On 05/21/20, the Governor announced that, effective 05/22/20 at 12:00am, landlords could file for emergency eviction where there was specific injury, loss or damage to the property. However, evictions for nonpayment were not permitted. On 07/30/20, after several extensions, the Governor announced that the moratorium was extended to 08/14/20.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Indiana could not issue notices to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords could file to evict tenants in Indiana who experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Indiana could still file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Indiana could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Orders in Indiana did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$intcareslink.$t: IN_SupremeCourt_Order_052720 [Supreme Court notes that lower courts "should inquire" but not that they "MUST inquire"]

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Indiana were not tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings in Indiana could continue to be held, although local courts have discretion to stay them.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Indiana.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Indiana.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Indiana could still enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Indiana could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Indiana could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Indiana did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: By executive order, utility providers in Indiana could not disconnect gas, electric, telecommunications, broadband, water, or wastewater service due to nonpayment through November 1, 2020.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in Indiana are required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Indiana did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Indiana were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Foreclosures actions and proceedings could not be initiated in Indiana.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Indiana could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Indiana did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance was available in Indiana during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, and further assistance became available later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Indiana did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/19/20, effective immediately, Gov. Reynolds suspended the statute allowing landlords to terminate tenancies and evict tenants, except for emergencies under law or the tenant occupied the premises by fraud, stealth, force, or intimidation. On 03/26/20, Gov. Reynolds suspended the statute requiring landlords to give notice and service of original notice prior to commencing an eviction. These orders were extended on 04/02 [until 04/30] and on 04/27/20. The 04/27/20 order was set to "expire on May 27, 2020, at 11:59 p.m." The IA Supreme Court issued an order on 03/17/20 that continued all forcible entry and detainer proceedings scheduled up to 05/04 until after 05/04, BUT that order allowed courts to hold FED proceedings by telephone if they chose. On 04/02/20, the IA Supreme Court issued an extension of this order up to 06/15 and noted that "any resumption of FED proceedings hereunder [was] subject to the terms of any proclamation issued by the Governor."

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Iowa could not give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Iowa could not file to evict tenants who experienced financial hardship during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Iowa could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Iowa could not file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Landlords in Iowa were required to certify that a dwelling was not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant. During this moratorium, however, no eviction filings were accepted by the courts.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Iowa were not tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings were not explicitly banned in Iowa.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Iowa.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Iowa.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Iowa could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Iowa could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Iowa could not remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Iowa did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: The Iowa Utilities Board ordered that utilities suspend disconnections of electric, natural gas, and water service for nonpayment during the pandemic.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in Iowa are required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Iowa did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Iowa were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Foreclosure proceedings were blocked in Iowa.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Iowa could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Iowa did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance wasn't available in Iowa during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, though it became available to Iowa renters later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Iowa did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

content.$t: stname: Kansas, intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 871,031, evstat2: 164,105, intstat3: 83,000, intstat4: 378,704, intstat5: 0, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 0, intstat7: 0, stars: 1.43, intinitiationscore: 0.3, intcourtscore: 0.1, intenfscore: 0, intsupportscore: 0.5, inttenscore: 0.5, sttext: On 03/18/20, effective upon filing, the KS Supreme Court issued an order limiting district courts to emergency operations, which did not include evictions proceedings; courts were prohibited from engaging in non-emergency operations. On 04/03/20, the high court allowed non-essential proceedings to be conducted via remote technology only. On 03/17/20, effective at 12:01pm 3/17/20, Gov. Kelly issued an order suspending any residential eviction "efforts" or judicial proceedings until 05/01/20. On 03/23/20, effective immediately, Gov. Kelly rescinded the 3/17/20 order with an order prohibiting any "landlord" from "evicting" a tenant where all defaults or violations of the rental agreement were substantially caused by financial hardship resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic. Financial hardship includes loss of income due directly or indirectly to the pandemic and that rent payments would make the tenant unable to purchase food, medicine, or other goods/supplies/services necessary to health. On 04/30/20, the Governor extended this order through 05/31/20. gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/18/20, effective upon filing, the KS Supreme Court issued an order limiting district courts to emergency operations, which did not include evictions proceedings; courts were prohibited from engaging in non-emergency operations. On 04/03/20, the high court allowed non-essential proceedings to be conducted via remote technology only. On 03/17/20, effective at 12:01pm 3/17/20, Gov. Kelly issued an order suspending any residential eviction "efforts" or judicial proceedings until 05/01/20. On 03/23/20, effective immediately, Gov. Kelly rescinded the 3/17/20 order with an order prohibiting any "landlord" from "evicting" a tenant where all defaults or violations of the rental agreement were substantially caused by financial hardship resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic. Financial hardship includes loss of income due directly or indirectly to the pandemic and that rent payments would make the tenant unable to purchase food, medicine, or other goods/supplies/services necessary to health. On 04/30/20, the Governor extended this order through 05/31/20. On 08/19/20, the Gov. re-issued the order prohibiting evictions and extended it on 09/10/20, on 1/26/21, and on 04/01/21, effective immediately, until the end of the disaster emergency (currently 5/28/21).

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Kansas could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Kansas could not file to evict tenants who experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Kansas could file to evict tenants for nonpayment.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Kansas could file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons other than nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Orders in Kansas did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Kansas were tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could be held in Kansas.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Kansas.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Kansas.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Kansas could enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Kansas could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Kansas could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Kansas did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Both the Kansas Corporation Commission and the Governor of Kansas have issued orders prohibiting disconnection of utilities for nonpayment during the pandemic.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in Kansas are required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Kansas did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Kansas were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Foreclosures were paused in Kansas for homeowners experiencing financial hardship due to COVID.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Kansas could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Kansas did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance was available statewide in Kansas during this eviction moratorium.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Kansas did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/13/20, the Kentucky Supreme Court announced, effective 03/16/20, that all eviction hearings would be continued. On 03/25/20, Gov. Beshear issued an order suspending all evictions and prohibiting enforcement of evictions. On 04/01/20, the KY Supreme Court announced, effective 03/16/20, that, pursuant to the CARES Act and the Governor's 03/25 Order, court clerks should not accept filings for evictions until 30 days after the expiration of its order and that hearings would continue to be suspended. On 05/08/20, the Governor amended the executive order to include only evictions resulting from the failure to pay rent. On 05/29/20, the Supreme Court, effective 06/01/20, limited the prohibition on filing and enforcement to cases for non-payment of rent. On 07/27/20, the high court announced that, effective 08/01/20, the moratorium on filings would end. On 08/24/20, effective 8/25/20, the Governor announced that the moratorium would end and that 30 days notice was required to evict a tenant for nonpayment of rent. A "meet and confer" is required during the 30 day period.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Kentucky could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Kentucky were barred from filing to evict tenants who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Kentucky could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Kentucky could not file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: When filings resumed in Kentucky, landlords were required to include a certification that the dwelling in question was not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Kentucky were not tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could not be heard in Kentucky, except for emergency matters.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Kentucky.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Kentucky.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Kentucky could enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Kentucky could enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the moratorium.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Kentucky could enforce eviction orders issued for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Kentucky did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Kentucky's Public Services Commission directed utility providers not to disconnect service for nonpayment during the pandemic.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in Kentucky are required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Kentucky did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Kentucky were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Kentucky did not address foreclosures.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Kentucky could charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Kentucky did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance wasn't available in Kentucky during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, though it became available to Kentucky renters later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Kentucky did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

content.$t: stname: Maine, intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 315,084, evstat2: 79,937, intstat3: 32,487, intstat4: 154,836, intstat5: 0, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 0, intstat7: 0, stars: 1.58, intinitiationscore: 0, intcourtscore: 0.4, intenfscore: 0.7, intsupportscore: 0.5, inttenscore: 0.5, sttext: On 03/18/20, effective immediately, the Maine Supreme Judicial Court issued an order that eviction actions would not be scheduled or heard. On 05/27/20, after two extensions, the high court announced it would begin hearing eviction actions again as of 08/03/20. On 04/16/20, effective immediately, Gov. Mills issued an order prohibiting the issuance or service of writs of eviction for nonpayment of rent. Exceptions include imminent risk of harm to property or person, code violation, illegal activity, nuisance, damage to property. The order included a prohibition on eviction of a tenant by means not authorized by law and gave law enforcement, with guidance from the Attorney General, authority to enforce provision. On 07/30/20, Gov. Mills rescinded this order, effective 08/03/20. The 7/30/20 order extended at will notice to quit from 30 to 45 days and the notice to a tenant for arrearage from 7 to 30 days., plcstandoutbool: 0, until: August 2, 2020, plcnoticebool: 0,
