gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/18/20, effective immediately, the Maine Supreme Judicial Court issued an order that eviction actions would not be scheduled or heard. On 05/27/20, after two extensions, the high court announced it would begin hearing eviction actions again as of 08/03/20. On 04/16/20, effective immediately, Gov. Mills issued an order prohibiting the issuance or service of writs of eviction for nonpayment of rent. Exceptions include imminent risk of harm to property or person, code violation, illegal activity, nuisance, damage to property. The order included a prohibition on eviction of a tenant by means not authorized by law and gave law enforcement, with guidance from the Attorney General, authority to enforce provision. On 07/30/20, Gov. Mills rescinded this order, effective 08/03/20. The 7/30/20 order extended at will notice to quit from 30 to 45 days and the notice to a tenant for arrearage from 7 to 30 days.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Maine could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords could file to evict tenants in Maine who experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Maine could still file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Maine could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Orders in Maine did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Maine were not tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could not be held in Maine.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction judgments in Maine were not stayed.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Maine.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Maine could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Maine could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Maine could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: The order in Maine was originally intended to extend past the end of the state of emergency, however, the order was repealed well before the actual end of the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: The Maine Public Utilities Commission directed that utility providers could not engage in disconnection activity, including issuing disconnection notices and actual service disconnections.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in Maine are required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Maine did not give tenants a grace period to repay back rent that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Maine were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Courts in Maine did not hear foreclosure cases during the moratorium.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Maine could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Maine did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: The MaineHousing COVID-19 Rent Relief Program provided one-time payments of $500 to address rental arrears during the moratorium. Additional rental assistance was also made available after the moratorium.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Maine did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/16/20, Gov. Hogan issued, effective immediately, an order that prohibited issuance of judgments or warrants of eviction to tenants who could demonstrate, through documentation, substantial loss of income resulting from COVID-19 due to job loss, reduced hours, closure of employment, care for school-age child. On 04/03/20, Gov. Hogan modified this order to also include commercial tenants.   This moratorium has since been reissued in orders dated 10/16/20 and 12/18/20.  On 03/18/20, the Chief Judge issued an order staying all new evictions upon filing, any pending eviction matters, and any outstanding eviction orders. On 05/22/20, the Chief Judge of the MD Court of Appeals issued an order stating that the stay on evictions would be lifted, effective 07/25/20. On 11/12/20, the Court of Appeals announced, effective 11/16/20, a return to Phase III, which stopped courts from hearing failure to pay rent cases but still allowed courts to process warrants of restitution in failure to pay rent actions commenced after 07/25/20. On 11/24/20, the Court of Appeals announced, effective 11/30/20, a return to Phase II, which continued the suspension on hearings and allowed courts to continue processing warrants of restitution. On 12/22/20, the Court of Appeals extended the return to Phase II through 03/12/21. On 02/16/21, the Court of Appeals clarified that Phase II operations would be extended through 03/14/21 and that the Maryland Courts would move directly from Phase II to Phase IV on 03/15/21.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Maryland could file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Maryland could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Maryland could enforce an order to remove a tenant who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Maryland could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Maryland could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Maryland did not extend past the state of emergency.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Utilities in Maryland were not required to reconnect suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Current orders in Maryland did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

content.$t: stname: Massachusetts, intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 2,214,898, evstat2: 505,852, intstat3: 247,562, intstat4: 980,861, intstat5: 0, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 0, intstat7: 0, stars: 4.03, intinitiationscore: 1, intcourtscore: 0.7, intenfscore: 1, intsupportscore: 0.5, inttenscore: 0.5, sttext: On 03/13/20, effective immediately, the MA Housing Court announced that it was continuing all non-emergency hearings, including summary process hearings, to a date "no earlier than 04/21/20." On 04/03/20, effective 04/06/20, this continuance was extended until 05/04/20. On 04/20/20, the General Court (legislative body) passed a bill creating a moratorium on all stages of eviction for 120 days that could be extended by the Governor. The bill included an exception for evictions due to criminal activity or lease violations that harmed others. On 07/21/20, the Governor extended the legislative moratorium to 10/17/20 at 11:59pm. The legislative moratorium then expired.  On 12/31/20, the MA General Court passed a bill, effective immediately, that authorized courts to stay proceedings or stay issuance of an execution in summary cases brought solely for non-payment of rent where the non-payment resulted from COVID-19 related financial hardship and the tenant had a pending application for rental assistance. The legislation states that "the court shall not enter a judgment or issue an execution before the [tenant's] application has been approved or denied." The legislation remains in effect during Massachusett's COVID-19 emergency., plcstandoutbool: 0, until: October 17, 2020, plcnoticebool: 1, plcnoticetext: Landlords in Massachusetts could not give Additional aid was made available after the moratorium expired., intdebtlink: https://www.mass.gov/info-details/emergency-housing-assistance-during-covid-19#details-on-the-emergency-rental-assistance-program-(erap)-, plccgbool: 0, plccgtext: Massachusetts did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/13/20, effective immediately, the MA Housing Court announced that it was continuing all non-emergency hearings, including summary process hearings, to a date "no earlier than 04/21/20." On 04/03/20, effective 04/06/20, this continuance was extended until 05/04/20. On 04/20/20, the General Court (legislative body) passed a bill creating a moratorium on all stages of eviction for 120 days that could be extended by the Governor. The bill included an exception for evictions due to criminal activity or lease violations that harmed others. On 07/21/20, the Governor extended the legislative moratorium to 10/17/20 at 11:59pm. The legislative moratorium then expired.  On 12/31/20, the MA General Court passed a bill, effective immediately, that authorized courts to stay proceedings or stay issuance of an execution in summary cases brought solely for non-payment of rent where the non-payment resulted from COVID-19 related financial hardship and the tenant had a pending application for rental assistance. The legislation states that "the court shall not enter a judgment or issue an execution before the [tenant's] application has been approved or denied." The legislation remains in effect during Massachusett's COVID-19 emergency.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Massachusetts could not give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Massachusetts could not file to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Massachusetts could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Massachusetts could not file to evict tenants, except for emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Landlords in Massachusetts were not required to certify whether dwellings were covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium, but could not file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons under state law regardless.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Deadlines in eviction cases in Massachusetts were tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Courts in Massachusetts could not schedule eviction hearings, except for emergency cases.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders could not be issued and were stayed in Massachusetts.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Massachusetts.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Massachusetts could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Massachusetts could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the moratorium.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Massachusetts could not enforce eviction orders issued for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: The eviction moratorium in Massachusetts was slated to last either 120 days or until 45 days after the end of the state of emergency. The moratorium did, however, end before the expiration of the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: The Department of Public Utilities of Massachusetts ordered that utilities companies under its jursidiction not shut off water, gas, or electric service to residents for failure to pay bills.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in Massachusetts are required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Massachusetts did not give tenants a grace period to repay backrent that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords and mortgagors in Massachusetts were prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies, but only if tenants can prove the non-payment was due to COVID-19 hardship.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Lenders could not proceed with foreclosures in Massachusetts.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Massachusetts could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Massachusetts did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: During this moratorium, Massachusetts introduced millions of dollars in new funding for rental assistance. Additional aid was made available after the moratorium expired.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Massachusetts did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

content.$t: stname: Michigan, intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 2,585,932, evstat2: 1,051,803, intstat3: 274,220, intstat4: 1,132,395, intstat5: 0, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 0, intstat7: 0, stars: 3.33, intinitiationscore: 1, intcourtscore: 0.1, intenfscore: 1, intsupportscore: 0, inttenscore: 0.5, sttext: On 03/20/20 [2020-19], Gov. Whitmer issued an order prohibiting any person from removing a tenant or a sheriff enforcing evictions or serving process except where the tenant created a substantial risk or imminent and severe risk to other persons or property. The order "does not affect the inherent power of the judge to order equitable relief." On 06/26/20 [2020-134], after several extensions [2020-54, 2020-85, 2020-118], the Governor issued an order ending the moratorium and replacing it with a diversion program as of 07/16/20 at 12:01am., plcstandoutbool: 0, until: July 15, 2020, plcnoticebool: 1, plcnoticetext: Landlords in Michigan could not give notice of eviction to tenants., plccofilbool: 1, plccofiltext: Landlords could not file to evict tenants in Michigan who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic., plcnonpbool: 1, plcnonptext: Landlords in Michigan could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent., plcnofilbool: 1, plcnofiltext: Landlords in Michigan could not file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons., plccaresbool: 1, plccarestext: Courts in Michigan required landlords to certify that a dwelling was not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant, though non-emergency eviction filings were not permitted under the state eviction moratorium., intcareslink: https://courts.michigan.gov/Courts/MichiganSupremeCourt/rules/court-rules-admin-matters/Administrative%20Orders/2020-08_2020-04-16_FormattedOrder_AO2020-8.pdf, plctldbool: 1, plctldtext: Court deadlines in Michigan were tolled., intplctldlink: https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/MIEOG/2020/06/26/file_attachments/1482995/Executive%20Order%202020-134.pdf, plcnohearbool: 0, plcnoheartext: Civil hearings in Michigan were required to be adjurned or held remotely. Eviction hearings were not explicitly suspended, and might have been able to be held remotely., plcnonewbool: 0, plcnonewtext: Eviction orders were not stayed in Michigan., plcsealbool: 0, plcsealtext: Eviction case records were not sealed in Michigan., plccovenfbool: 1, plccovenftext: Law enforcement in Michigan could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic., plcpayenfbool: 1, plcpayenftext: Law enforcement in Michigan could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic., plcnoenfbool: 1, plcnoenftext: Law enforcement in Michigan could not enforce eviction orders issued for non-emergency reasons., plcextmorbool: 0, plcextmortext: Current orders in Michigan did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency., plcnoshbool: 0, plcnoshtext: The Governor of Michigan issued an executive order prohibiting water shut offs and requiring utilities to reconnect water services to homes that had their water shut off due to non-payment (unless the utility has reason to believe reconnecting water would create a public health risk). However, no order from the governor or Michigan's Public Service Commission prevented disconnections of other utilities, like electricity and natural gas., plcfrrcbool: 0, plcfrrctext: Water utilities were required to restore service to residents whose water was shut off due to nonpayment. Orders did not make it clear if other utility companies in Michigan are required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee., intplcfrrclink: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-522509--,00.html, plcarsbool: 0, plcarstext: Orders in Michigan did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic., intplcarslink: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-526305--,00.html, plcnorepbool: 0, plcnoreptext: Landlords in Michigan were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies., intnoreplink: No relevant order., plcnofcbool: 0, plcnofctext: Orders in Michigan did not directly address foreclosures., plcnofclink: https://www.michigan.gov/whitmer/0,9309,7-387-90499_90705-526305--,00.html, plclatfbool: 0, plclatftext: Landlords in Michigan could still charge late fees., plcraisebool: 0, plcraisetext: Orders in Michigan did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic., plcdebtbool: 1, plcdebttext: Michigan established a statewide Eviction Diversion Program that provided rental assistance to clear tenants' rental debts from not being able to pay rent due to the pandemic., intdebtlink: https://www.michigan.gov/mshda/0,4641,7-141-5555-533463--,00.html, plccgbool: 0, plccgtext: Michigan did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/20/20 [2020-19], Gov. Whitmer issued an order prohibiting any person from removing a tenant or a sheriff enforcing evictions or serving process except where the tenant created a substantial risk or imminent and severe risk to other persons or property. The order "does not affect the inherent power of the judge to order equitable relief." On 06/26/20 [2020-134], after several extensions [2020-54, 2020-85, 2020-118], the Governor issued an order ending the moratorium and replacing it with a diversion program as of 07/16/20 at 12:01am.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Michigan could not give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords could not file to evict tenants in Michigan who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Michigan could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Michigan could not file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Michigan required landlords to certify that a dwelling was not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant, though non-emergency eviction filings were not permitted under the state eviction moratorium.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Michigan were tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Civil hearings in Michigan were required to be adjurned or held remotely. Eviction hearings were not explicitly suspended, and might have been able to be held remotely.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Michigan.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Michigan.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Michigan could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Michigan could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Michigan could not enforce eviction orders issued for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Current orders in Michigan did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: The Governor of Michigan issued an executive order prohibiting water shut offs and requiring utilities to reconnect water services to homes that had their water shut off due to non-payment (unless the utility has reason to believe reconnecting water would create a public health risk). However, no order from the governor or Michigan's Public Service Commission prevented disconnections of other utilities, like electricity and natural gas.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Water utilities were required to restore service to residents whose water was shut off due to nonpayment. Orders did not make it clear if other utility companies in Michigan are required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Michigan did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Michigan were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Michigan did not directly address foreclosures.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Michigan could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Michigan did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Michigan established a statewide Eviction Diversion Program that provided rental assistance to clear tenants' rental debts from not being able to pay rent due to the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Michigan did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

On 03/20/20, effective 3/23/20, the high court issued an order superseding its 03/13/20 order and authorizing presiding judge to conduct evictions remotely or based on parties' written submissions. On 03/23/20, effective 03/24/20 at 5pm, Gov. Walz announced a moratorium on filing, termination of leases, and enforcement of evictions, excepting evictions where the tenant endangered residents or conducts illegal activity on the property as included in code. On 06/05/20, Gov. Walz revised the moratorium to include an exception where a tenant violated the lease by endangering non-residents. On 07/14/20, effective 08/04/20 at 12:00 am. the Governor issued an executive order that created a ban on filings and also created further exceptions for when a tenant held over after a property owner gave a notice to vacate because the property owner planned to occupy the property. This order also allowed sheriffs to enforce writs of eviction issued before the Governor's 03/23 order went into effect on 3/24/20 at 5pm. On 01/13/21, Gov. Walz extended the peacetime emergency, and with it the eviction moratorium, through 02/12/21. gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/13/20, the MN Supreme Court announced that, effective 03/16/20, non-emergency eviction cases suspended through 03/30/20. On 03/20/20, effective 3/23/20, the high court issued an order superseding its 03/13/20 order and authorizing presiding judge to conduct evictions remotely or based on parties' written submissions. On 03/23/20, effective 03/24/20 at 5pm, Gov. Walz announced a moratorium on filing, termination of leases, and enforcement of evictions, excepting evictions where the tenant endangered residents or conducts illegal activity on the property as included in code. On 06/05/20, Gov. Walz revised the moratorium to include an exception where a tenant violated the lease by endangering non-residents. On 07/14/20, effective 08/04/20 at 12:00 am. the Governor issued an executive order that created a ban on filings and also created further exceptions for when a tenant held over after a property owner gave a notice to vacate because the property owner planned to occupy the property. This order also allowed sheriffs to enforce writs of eviction issued before the Governor's 03/23 order went into effect on 3/24/20 at 5pm. On 01/13/21, Gov. Walz extended the peacetime emergency, and with it the eviction moratorium, through 02/12/21. On 05/14/21, the Governor extended the moratorium through 06/14/21.

gsx$intwtxp.$t: Executive order covers duration of SOE

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Minnesota could not give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Orders in Minnesota prevented landlords from filing to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Minnesota could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Minnesota could not file to evict tenants, except for emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Landlords in Minnesota were not required to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant, however, eviction filings were prohibited under a state emergency order.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Minnesota were not tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings were not held in Minnesota, with the exception of remote, emergency hearings.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Minnesota. However, new judgments were not likely to be issued until hearings resume.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Minnesota court officials can seal eviction records, but the process is not automatic, even for cases started during the pandemic.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Minnesota could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Minnesota could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the moratorium.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Minnesota could not enforce eviction orders issued for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Minnesota did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Minnesota's governor and Public Utilities Commission suspended utility disconnections for the duration of the peacetime emergency.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in Minnesota were required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Minnesota did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Minnesota werenot prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Foreclosures were halted in Minnesota for the duration of the public health emergency.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Minnesota could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Minnesota did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: As of May 11, 2021, renters in Minnesota can apply for rental assistance through Rent Help Minnesota (RentHelpMN).

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Minnesota did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 04/01/20, effective at 5:00pm on 04/03/20, Gov. Reeves issued an order suspending evictions and directing all law enforcement officers to cease enforcing orders of eviction "during this Shelter in Place Order."  On 05/14/20, after two extension of the initial order, Gov. Reeves announced that the moratorium would "sunset at 8:00 a.m. on Monday, June 1, 2020."

gsx$intwtxp.$t: Protections in EO 1477, extended by EO 1480 (released 5/8/20)

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Mississippi could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Orders in Mississippi did not prevent landlords from filing to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Mississippi could still file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Mississippi could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Landlords in Mississippi were not required to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant, however, eviction filings were prohibited under a state emergency order.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Mississippi were not tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could still be heard in Mississippi.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Mississippi.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Mississippi.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Mississippi could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Mississippi could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the moratorium.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Mississippi could not enforce eviction orders issued for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Mississippi did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Mississippi's Public Service Commission initially ordered utilities not to disconnect water, sewer, natural gas, and electric services for reason of nonpayment, but this order expired on May 26.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Utilities in Mississippi were not required to reconnect suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Mississippi did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accures during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Mississippi were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Mississippi did not directly address foreclosure proceedings.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Mississippi could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Mississippi did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance wasn't available in Mississippi during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, though it became available to Mississippi renters later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Mississippi did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: Missouri did not implement any statewide eviction moratorium during the pandemic. Rental assistance was available to renters in Missouri at some points during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Missouri could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Orders in Missouri did not prevent landlords from filing to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Missouri could still file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Missouri could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Missouri did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not subject to the CARES Act federal eviction moratorium when filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Missouri were not tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could still be held in Missouri.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Missouri.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Missouri.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Missouri could still enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Missouri could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Missouri could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Missouri did not extend past the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Neither Missouri's governor nor the state's Public Service Commission issued an order requiring utilities to suspend service shutoffs during the pandemic. The Public Service Commission approved requests from individual utilities to suspend disconnections.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Missouri's governor and Public Service Commission did not take action to require utilities to reconnect utilities service without fees during the pandemic.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Missouri did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Missouri were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Missouri did not address foreclosures.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Missouri could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Missouri did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Missouri did not institute an eviction moratorium at any point during the study period. Rental assistance, including from the federal government, was available at some points during the study period.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Missouri has not guaranteed legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

content.$t: stname: Montana, intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 305,301, evstat2: 67,458, intstat3: 27,853, intstat4: 136,687, intstat5: 0, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 0, intstat7: 0, stars: 2.29, intinitiationscore: 0.6, intcourtscore: 0, intenfscore: 0.7, intsupportscore: 0.625, inttenscore: 0.25, sttext: On 03/30/20, effective immediately, Gov. Bullock issued a "directive" prohibiting actions for termination of tenancy posssession, unlawful holdover, or rent; or enforcement of an order of eviction. The order requested courts stay pending actions. The order prohibited landlords from terminating a tenancy or refusing to renew a tenancy at least on a month to month basis. The order does not apply to termination outside nonpayment or damage/destruction to premises, criminal activity, threat to health and safety. On 04/13/20, Gov. Bullock limited the protections of the moratorium to nonpayment of rent and to individuals in the following categories who provided documentation to their landlords: (1) individuals required to quarantine because of a COVID-19 diagnosis; (2) individuals required to quarantine by a Directive from the Governor, a health authority, or where an individual had reason to believe quarantining was in the best interest of public health; (3) individuals over 65 or with a high-risk health condition (4) individuals who suffered a substantial loss of income from COVID-19.  On 05/19/20, Gov. Bullock issued an order extending the moratorium until 05/24/20. After 05/24/20, for "vulnerable populations," who suffered significant financial hardship as a result of the pandemic, the protections expire EITHER the end of the emergency OR 30 days after the individual ceases to to shelter at home, WHICHEVER IS SOONER. Landlords must provide notice of the directive before initiating eviction., plcstandoutbool: 1, until: April 12, 2020, intwtxp: Executive Order, plcnoticebool: 0, plcnoticetext: Landlords in Montana gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/30/20, effective immediately, Gov. Bullock issued a "directive" prohibiting actions for termination of tenancy posssession, unlawful holdover, or rent; or enforcement of an order of eviction. The order requested courts stay pending actions. The order prohibited landlords from terminating a tenancy or refusing to renew a tenancy at least on a month to month basis. The order does not apply to termination outside nonpayment or damage/destruction to premises, criminal activity, threat to health and safety. On 04/13/20, Gov. Bullock limited the protections of the moratorium to nonpayment of rent and to individuals in the following categories who provided documentation to their landlords: (1) individuals required to quarantine because of a COVID-19 diagnosis; (2) individuals required to quarantine by a Directive from the Governor, a health authority, or where an individual had reason to believe quarantining was in the best interest of public health; (3) individuals over 65 or with a high-risk health condition (4) individuals who suffered a substantial loss of income from COVID-19.  On 05/19/20, Gov. Bullock issued an order extending the moratorium until 05/24/20. After 05/24/20, for "vulnerable populations," who suffered significant financial hardship as a result of the pandemic, the protections expire EITHER the end of the emergency OR 30 days after the individual ceases to to shelter at home, WHICHEVER IS SOONER. Landlords must provide notice of the directive before initiating eviction.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Montana could give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Montana could not file to evict tenants who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Montana could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Montana could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Montana did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not subject to the CARES Act federal eviction moratorium when filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$intcareslink.$t: https://covid19.mt.gov/Portals/223/Documents/Phase%20Two%20Directive%20with%20Appendices.pdf?ver=2020-05-19-145442-350; Guidance Memo referred to in Supreme Court Order: https://courts.mt.gov/Portals/189/virus/Memo%20Re%20Guidance%20on%20Evictions%20under%20May%2019%20Directive.pdf?ver=2020-05-22-092927-153

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines related to eviction in Montana were not tolled.

gsx$intplctldlink.$t: Landlords were prohibited from terminating any lease before the issuance of the 4/17 order.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could still be held in Montana.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Montana.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Montana.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Montana could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Montana could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Montana could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Montana did not extend past the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: By executive order of the governor of Montana, utilities could not disconnect service for reason of nonpayment of bills.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in Montana were required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Montana did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Montana were prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Foreclosures were paused in Montana.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Montana could not charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Landlords in Montana could not increase rent during the moratorium.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance wasn't available in Montana during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, though it became available to Montana renters later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Montana has not guaranteed legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

Sisolak issued an order prohibiting notice, filing, or continuation of an eviction for a tenant's default on any term of a rental contract, but allowed pre-03/12/20 actions and actions where the tenant "seriously endanger the public or other residents, engage in criminal activity, or cause significant damage to property." On 06/25/20, the Governor issued an order encouraging the use of payment plans and providing a model promissory note, which would cancel any eviction proceeding and narrowing the protections in the 03/29 order by allowing, effective 7/21/20 at 11:59pm, eviction for continued possession after lease term, tenant at will, subletting contrary to lease, nuisance violation, substace abuse violation, unlawful business, or lease violation. On 08/31/20, effective 08/31/20 at 11:59pm, the Governor limited the previous order to "the initiation of a nonpayment of rent summary eviction action by service of a pay or quit notice" through 10/14/20 at 11:59 p.m. On 12/14/20, Gov. Sisolak announced, effective 12/15/20, a moratorium on nonpayment of rent eviction causes of action, including no lock out, notice, eviction or other proceeding, where a tenant could demonstrate they had suffered a financial impact of COVID-19 or would be made homeless by eviction (uses CDC definition) and submits a "covered persons declaration" or the CDC declaration. Allows landlord to challenge eligibility by presenting evidence.  On 03/31/21, Gov. gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/29/20, effective 03/29/20 at 11:59pm, Gov. Sisolak issued an order prohibiting notice, filing, or continuation of an eviction for a tenant's default on any term of a rental contract, but allowed pre-03/12/20 actions and actions where the tenant "seriously endanger the public or other residents, engage in criminal activity, or cause significant damage to property." On 06/25/20, the Governor issued an order encouraging the use of payment plans and providing a model promissory note, which would cancel any eviction proceeding and narrowing the protections in the 03/29 order by allowing, effective 7/21/20 at 11:59pm, eviction for continued possession after lease term, tenant at will, subletting contrary to lease, nuisance violation, substace abuse violation, unlawful business, or lease violation. On 08/31/20, effective 08/31/20 at 11:59pm, the Governor limited the previous order to "the initiation of a nonpayment of rent summary eviction action by service of a pay or quit notice" through 10/14/20 at 11:59 p.m. On 12/14/20, Gov. Sisolak announced, effective 12/15/20, a moratorium on nonpayment of rent eviction causes of action, including no lock out, notice, eviction or other proceeding, where a tenant could demonstrate they had suffered a financial impact of COVID-19 or would be made homeless by eviction (uses CDC definition) and submits a "covered persons declaration" or the CDC declaration. Allows landlord to challenge eligibility by presenting evidence.  On 03/31/21, Gov. Sisolak extended the order until "11:59 PM on" 5/31/21.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords could not give notice of eviction to tenants in Nevada.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Nevada could not file to evict a tenant who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Nevada could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Nevada could not file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Landlords in Nevada were not required to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant, however, filings were not accepted during the moratorium.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Nevada were not explicitly tolled, however, all parts of the eviction process were frozen by executive order.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could not be held in Nevada during the moratorium.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction judgments in Nevada were stayed.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Nevada courts seal eviction case records if the action is denied or the case dismissed and have discretion in other cases.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Nevada could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Nevada could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Nevada could not remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Nevada were not scheduled to extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Nevada's governor and Public Utilities Commission have not taken action to require utilities to suspend service shutoffs during the pandemic.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Nevada's governor and Public Utilities Commission have not taken action to require utilities to suspend service shutoffs during the pandemic.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Current orders in Nevada did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic. An executive order in Nevada encouraged landlords to reach a deal with tenants about repaying rent.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Nevada were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Foreclosure hearings were paused in Nevada.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords could not charge late fees in Nevada during the moratorium.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Nevada did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Nevada allocated new funds for rental assistance during the moratorium, and additional funding became available after the moratorium was phased out and expired.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Nevada did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/17/20, Gov. Sununu issued an emergency order that prohibited initiating an eviction, along with the issuance or execution of an order of eviction. On 04/03/20, the Gov. clarified that the emergency order did not apply evictions resulting damage to property or from lease violations that harmed others. This order was extended until, on 06/11/20, Gov. Sununu announced that the moratorium would lapse as of 07/01/20.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords could not give notice of eviction to tenants in New Hampshire.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: An executive order in New Hampshire prevented landlords from filing to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in New Hampshire could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in New Hampshire could not file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Landlords in New Hampshire were required to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in eviction cases in New Hampshire were tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Local courts had discretion to hear non-emergency or emergency eviction cases remotely. It is unlikely that cases were heard, however, as the courts did not accept eviction filings during the moratorium.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were stayed in New Hampshire.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in New Hampshire.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in New Hampshire could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in New Hampshire could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in New Hampshire could not enforce eviction orders issued for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in New Hampshire did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Under Emergency Order #3, the Governor of New Hampshire directed utilities supplying electric, gas, water, telephone, voice over internet protocol (VoIP), internet service, and all deliverable fuels, not to disconnect service for nonpayment.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in New Hampshire were required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in New Hampshire did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in New Hampshire were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Courts in New Hampshire did not hear foreclosure cases.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in New Hampshire could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in New Hampshire did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: New Hampshire put in place a Housing Relief Program that provided one-time assistance grants to households affected by the pandemic. More assistance became available after the end of the moratorium.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: New Hampshire did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/14/20, effective 03/16/20 to 03/27/20, the Chief Justice issued a notice of a two week suspension of all L/T calendars but allowing filings. On 3/27/20, the Supreme Court issued an order extending the the terms of the 3/14/20 notice to 04/26/20. From 04/24/20, the Chief Justice noted that efforts to resolve L/T cases will continue while trials suspended.  As of 07/14/20, the Chief Justice issued an order allowing Ls to file Order to Show Cause for Eviction in cases where there was an emergency (explicitly defined not to include non-payment of rent. Examples include violence, criminal activity, health and safety concerns). Other nonpayment of rent cases remained suspended. On 03/19/20, effective immediately, Gov. Murphy issued an order allowing the intiation of eviction proceedings and staying writs of possession and enforcement of orders of eviction. Gov. Murphy's order continues in effect (until 2 mos. after the end of the state of emergency and the Supreme Court's order halting trials also continues in effect [last update 8th Omnibus Order, 09/18/20]). Governor's emergency order expires every 30 days unless Gov. Murphy reissues.

gsx$intwtxp.$t: Landlord/tenant calendars suspended (no hearings) until 05/31 by Supreme Court Order; no filings or execution of orders until end of pandemic

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in New Jersey could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: The New Jersey eviction moratorium did not prevent landlords from filing to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in New Jersey could still file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in New Jersey could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: An order in New Jersey required landlords to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in New Jersey were not tolled during the entire moratorium.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could not be held in New Jersey until two months after the Governor declares an end to the COVID-19 Health crisis.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were stayed in New Jersey until two months after the Governor declares an end to the COVID-19 Health crisis.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in New Jersey.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in New Jersey could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in New Jersey could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the moratorium.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in New Jersey could not enforce eviction orders issued for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: The executive order in New Jersey that prohibits enforcement of evictions extends through the duration of the state of emergency and a period of two months following the end of the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: By executive order, Internet and voice service cannot be disconnected for reason of nonpayment until 30 days after the public health emergency has ended; utility providers-- including electric, gas, and water utilities--are also prohibited from disconnecting service for nonpayment.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: By executive order, electric, gas, water, internet, and voice service that was disconnected for reason of nonpayment must be reconnected.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in New Jersey did not create a grace period for tenants to pay rent.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in New Jersey were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Courts in New Jersey could in theory still hear foreclosure cases, but the Governor's executive order prohibited the enforcement of foreclosure judgments.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in New Jersey could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in New Jersey did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic. The New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency has voluntarily suspended rent increases for eligible properties (about 36,000 units).

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: New Jersey created a $100 million fund to aid renters. Additional assistance also became available during the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: New Jersey has not guaranteed legal counsel to tenants who face eviction. Newark gurantees a right to counsel in eviction proceedings to tenants under 200% of the Federal Poverty Level.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/24/20, the NM Supreme Court ordered a stay executions of writs in cases where the tenant demonstrated inability to pay rent by a "preponderance of the evidence." On 03/26/20, the high court also stayed writs for non-payment for mobile home tenants. Remains in effect until amended or withdrawn by future order of the Court.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in New Mexico could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: The moratorium in New Mexico did not prevent landlords from filing to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlord in New Mexico could still file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in New Mexico could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Orders in New Mexico did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in New Mexico were not tolled for the duration of the moratorium.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could still be held in New Mexico.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders in New Mexico were only stayed if the tenant could prove inability to pay rent during a phone or audiovisual court hearing.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in New Mexico.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Courts in New Mexico were ordered to stay eviction judgments for tenants who demonstrate they have been financially affected by COVID-19 and now cannot pay rent.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Courts in New Mexico were ordered to stay eviction judgments for tenants who demonstrate an inability to pay rent.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in New Mexico could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders, as long as the tenant does not prove inability to pay rent in a hearing.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in New Mexico did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: New Mexico's Public Regulation Commission prohibited utility companies subject to their jursdiction from disconnecting residential utility service for reason of nonpayment during the pandemic.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in New Mexico are required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in New Mexico did not create a grace period for tenants to pay rent.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in New Mexico were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Courts in New Mexico could still hear foreclosure cases.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in New Mexico could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in New Mexico did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: New Mexico allocated hundreds of millions of dollars in aid to renters who couldn't pay rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: New Mexico did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

content.$t: stname: New York, intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 8,207,322, evstat2: 1,310,931, intstat3: 953,937, intstat4: 3,373,181, intstat5: 0, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 0, intstat7: 0, stars: 3.25, intinitiationscore: 0.8, intcourtscore: 0.7, intenfscore: 1, intsupportscore: 0.5, inttenscore: 0.125, sttext: On 03/15/20, the Chief Administrative Judge announced that, effective 5pm on 03/16/20, all eviction proceedings and all eviction orders would be suspended. On 03/22/20, the Chief Administrative Judge announced that non-essential filings, which included evictions for non-payment for rent, would be suspended. Essential housing matters included landlord lockout, serious code violation or repair order, and post-eviction relief. On 06/18/20, the Judge announced, effective 06/20/20, that courts would again begin accepting eviction filings and required that a notice informing tenants that they may be eligible for time extension be included. The order also provided that eviction cases commenced prior to or on 3/16/20 would be eligible for virtual settlement. On 08/12/20, the Chief Administrative Judge announced that cases filed before 3/17/20 could commence and enforcement of evictions would re-commence on 10/01/20. On 10/09/20, the Chief Administrative Judge allowed eviction matters to proceed, effective 10/12/20. On 03/20/20 Gov. Cuomo issued an order prohibiting enforcement of residential evictions with no exceptions listed for 90 days. On 05/07/20, this ban was extended until 06/20/20 and tenants were allowed to use their security deposit towards the rent. From 06/20/20 through 07/06/20 [EO 202.48], the Governor's 05/07 order prohibited initiation of a proceeding or enforcement of an eviction for non-payment of rent where the tenant could demonstrate COVID-19 related financial hardship or the receipt of unemployment benefits. EO 202.48, issued 7/06/20, did not continue the stage 2 freeze. On 09/29/20, the Governor announced a ban on enforcement of evictions for tenants who could demonstrate COVID-19 related hardship, including where the order of eviction was issued prior to 03/07/20. This order has been extended several times and is currently extended until 06/16/21. On 06/30/20, legislation was enacted that allowed tenants to assert COVID-19 related hardship as a defense to the court issuing an order of eviction until the end of the Governor's state of emergency. On 12/28/20, the legislature passed a bill that stayed all pending cases and cases filed within 30 days for 60 days; the bill also provides that an eviction may not be filed, go to judgment or be enforced before 05/01/21 so long as the tenant provides a hardship declaration to their landlord, the court, or an official enforcing an eviction. On 05/05/21, the Governor signed into law that extended the 12/28 legislation to 8/31/21., plcstandoutbool: 1, until: June 19, 2020, plcnoticebool: 0, plcnoticetext: Landlords in New York could still gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/15/20, the Chief Administrative Judge announced that, effective 5pm on 03/16/20, all eviction proceedings and all eviction orders would be suspended. On 03/22/20, the Chief Administrative Judge announced that non-essential filings, which included evictions for non-payment for rent, would be suspended. Essential housing matters included landlord lockout, serious code violation or repair order, and post-eviction relief. On 06/18/20, the Judge announced, effective 06/20/20, that courts would again begin accepting eviction filings and required that a notice informing tenants that they may be eligible for time extension be included. The order also provided that eviction cases commenced prior to or on 3/16/20 would be eligible for virtual settlement. On 08/12/20, the Chief Administrative Judge announced that cases filed before 3/17/20 could commence and enforcement of evictions would re-commence on 10/01/20. On 10/09/20, the Chief Administrative Judge allowed eviction matters to proceed, effective 10/12/20. On 03/20/20 Gov. Cuomo issued an order prohibiting enforcement of residential evictions with no exceptions listed for 90 days. On 05/07/20, this ban was extended until 06/20/20 and tenants were allowed to use their security deposit towards the rent. From 06/20/20 through 07/06/20 [EO 202.48], the Governor's 05/07 order prohibited initiation of a proceeding or enforcement of an eviction for non-payment of rent where the tenant could demonstrate COVID-19 related financial hardship or the receipt of unemployment benefits. EO 202.48, issued 7/06/20, did not continue the stage 2 freeze. On 09/29/20, the Governor announced a ban on enforcement of evictions for tenants who could demonstrate COVID-19 related hardship, including where the order of eviction was issued prior to 03/07/20. This order has been extended several times and is currently extended until 06/16/21. On 06/30/20, legislation was enacted that allowed tenants to assert COVID-19 related hardship as a defense to the court issuing an order of eviction until the end of the Governor's state of emergency. On 12/28/20, the legislature passed a bill that stayed all pending cases and cases filed within 30 days for 60 days; the bill also provides that an eviction may not be filed, go to judgment or be enforced before 05/01/21 so long as the tenant provides a hardship declaration to their landlord, the court, or an official enforcing an eviction. On 05/05/21, the Governor signed into law that extended the 12/28 legislation to 8/31/21.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in New York could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Courts in New York did not accept eviction filings, so landlords could not file to evict tenants who experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Courts in New York did not accept eviction filings, so landlords could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Courts in New York did not accept eviction filings, so landlords could not file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in New York did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant, however, filings were not accepted during the state moratorium.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in New York were tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could not be held in New York.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were stayed in New York.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in New York.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in New York could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in New York could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in New York could not enforce eviction orders issued for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in New York did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: New York enacted legislation that prohibits utility shutoffs.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Legislation in New York required that utilities disconnected for reason of nonpayment be reconnected.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Landlords in New York were not required to give tenants a grace period of time to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in New York were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Courts in New York did not hear foreclosure cases.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in New York could not charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in New York did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance wasn't available in New York during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, though it became available to New York renters later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: New York has not guaranteed legal counsel to tenants who face eviction. New York City gurantees a right to counsel in eviction proceedings to tenants under 200% of the Federal Poverty Level.

On 03/15/20, the Chief Justice explained that ejectment actions were non-essential proceedings that must be postponed. This order was extended on 04/02/20 and on 05/30/20 until 06/21/20, and sheriffs were not required to execute writs of possession until 07/30/20.  The order also established a voluntary mediation program for eviction. On 05/30/20, Gov. Cooper issued an executive order that prohibited residential landlords from initiating or furthering an eviction action for nonpayment of rent. The order required opportunity to enter a 6 month payment plan during moratorium. This order was set to expire and did expire 21 days later, on 06/20/20. On 10/28/20, Gov. Cooper issued an order requiring landlords in any eviction action commenced on or after 10/28/20 to provide tenants with a blank copy of the CDC Declaration and to file an affidavit acknowledging their compliance with this requirement with the court. A landlord who receives a completed CDC Declaration from the tenant is prohibited from requesting a writ of eviction but can file a response with the court arguing that the CDC Declaration should not prevent the eviction action from moving forward. This order has been extended on 12/30/20, 01/27/21, and 3/30/21 and remains in effect "through and including" 06/30/21. gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/13/20, effective 03/16/20, the NC Supreme Court ordered that all non-essential in-person proceedings be scheduled or reschedule no sooner than 30 days from the issuance of its order, but allowed for remote hearings and for judges to hold proceedings if they felt it was safe. On 03/15/20, the Chief Justice explained that ejectment actions were non-essential proceedings that must be postponed. This order was extended on 04/02/20 and on 05/30/20 until 06/21/20, and sheriffs were not required to execute writs of possession until 07/30/20.  The order also established a voluntary mediation program for eviction. On 05/30/20, Gov. Cooper issued an executive order that prohibited residential landlords from initiating or furthering an eviction action for nonpayment of rent. The order required opportunity to enter a 6 month payment plan during moratorium. This order was set to expire and did expire 21 days later, on 06/20/20. On 10/28/20, Gov. Cooper issued an order requiring landlords in any eviction action commenced on or after 10/28/20 to provide tenants with a blank copy of the CDC Declaration and to file an affidavit acknowledging their compliance with this requirement with the court. A landlord who receives a completed CDC Declaration from the tenant is prohibited from requesting a writ of eviction but can file a response with the court arguing that the CDC Declaration should not prevent the eviction action from moving forward. This order has been extended on 12/30/20, 01/27/21, and 3/30/21 and remains in effect "through and including" 06/30/21. On 12/14/20, the NC Supreme Court announced that all hearings would be rescheduled to a date after 01/14/21.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in North Carolina could give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: An executive order in North Carolina prevented landlords from filing to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in North Carolina could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in North Carolina could file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Landlords in North Carolina were required to certify that a dwelling is not subject to the CARES Act federal eviction moratorium.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in North Carolina were not tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could not be held in North Carolina.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were stayed in North Carolina.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in North Carolina.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in North Carolina could still enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in North Carolina could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in North Carolina could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: The moratorium orders in North Carolina did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: North Carolina's governor ordered that all jursidictional electric, natural gas, water, and wastewater public utilities cease disconnecting service due to nonpayment of bills.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: North Carolina's governor ordered that all jurisdictional electric, natural gas, water, and wastewater public utilities suspend "all barriers" to reconnecting service, which should indicate that utilities would be reconnected without fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: During the moratorium in North Carolina, landlords were required to grant tenants a grace period of 6 months to pay rental debt that accrued from May 30 to June 20, but not rent due after that Effective Period.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in North Carolina were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: The North Carolina eviction moratorium did not explicitly pause foreclosure proceedings.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in North Carolina could not charge late fees during the Effective Period of June 1-21, 2020.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in North Carolina did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: New emergency rental assistance was not available to renters in North Carolina during the eviction moratorium. After the end of the state moratorium, hundreds of millions of dollars of rental assistance became available in North Carolina.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: North Carolina did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/16/20, effective 3/16/20, ND Supreme Court issued an order that stated continuances and extensions requests related to COVID-19 should be presumptively granted and gave local judges discretion until 04/24/20 to cancel civil hearings. Effective 03/26/20, the high court then issued an order suspending "residential eviction proceedings," except for good cause. On 04/23/20, the court amended that order to allow for proceedings to move forward remotely or in person.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Orders in North Dakota did not prevent landlords from filing to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in North Dakota could file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in North Dakota could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in North Dakota could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in North Dakota could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in North Dakota did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Neither North Dakota's governor nor the Public Service Commission issued an order requiring utilities to suspend service shutoffs during the pandemic.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: North Dakota's governor and Public Service Commission did not take action to require utilities to suspend service shutoffs during the pandemic.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Landlords in North Dakota were not required to give tenants a grace period of time to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders North Dakota did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Ohio's Public Utilities Commission issued an order directing all jurisdictional electric, natural gas, water, and wastewater distribution utilities to review service disconnection policies, but it did not issue an order prohibiting disconnections. Emergency legislation prohibited public water services from disconnecting service due to nonpayment. The Public Utilities Commission suspended non-essential work, which could include disconnecting service.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Ohio did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Ohio did not institute an eviction moratorium at any point during the study period. Rental assistance, including from the federal government, was available at some points during the study period.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Ohio has not guaranteed legal counsel to tenants who face eviction. Cleveland gurantees a right to counsel in eviction proceedings to tenants at or under 100% of the Federal Poverty Level.

content.$t: stname: Oregon, intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 1,448,791, evstat2: 202,076, intstat3: 145,315, intstat4: 606,312, intstat5: 0, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 0, intstat7: 0, stars: 2.73, intinitiationscore: 0.6, intcourtscore: 0, intenfscore: 0.7, intsupportscore: 0.75, inttenscore: 0.625, sttext: On 03/16/20, the OR Supreme Court issued an order that required all courts to, effective 03/19/20, continue hearings in forcible entry and detainer proceedings until 03/27; this order was then extended 03/27/20 and 05/15/20, when the high court stated that trials in FED matters would not take place until after 07/01 and allowed filings. On 03/22/20, Gov. Brown issued an order prohibiting enforcement of evictions for non-payment of rent for 90 days [06/20/20]. On 04/01/20, Gov. Brown issued an order prohibiting termination of a tenancy for non-payment of rent through notice, filing, for 90 days [06/30/20]. On 06/24/20, the OR legislature passed a bill that prohibited a landlord from initiating or continuing an action to take possession of a dwelling unit based on nonpayment of rent until 09/30/20. After the emergency period, a tenant has a 6 month grace period that ends on 3/31/21 to pay balance. On 10/01/20, Gov. Brown issued an order instating a moratorium on notice, filing or continuation of an eviction action for non-payment. The order extends the year of occupancy until after the moratorium ends. On 12/17/20, the Governor affirmed that the 10/01 order would extend through 12/31/20, as confirmed by the Governor's General Counsel.  On 12/23/20, the Oregon legislature passed a bill extending a moratorium on notice and filing until 06/30/21 for those tenants who provided a declaration of COVID hardship to their landlords until 06/30/21. On 5/20/21, the legislature passed a bill, effective 07/01/21, extending the moratorium on notice and filing to 02/28/22. The same legislation also prohibited landlords from charging late fees on rent that comes due during that period; prohibited landlords from reporting deliquent balances that accrued during this period to credit agencies; and gave tenants a grace period to pay accrued rent at any time until 02/28/21., plcstandoutbool: 1, until: December 31, 2020, plcnoticebool: 0, plcnoticetext: Landlords in Oregon could still give notice of eviction to tenants., intnoticelink: https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-56.pdf, plccofilbool: 1, plccofiltext: Landlords in Oregon could not file to evict tenants who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic., intcofillink: https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-56.pdf, plcnonpbool: 1, plcnonptext: Landlords in Oregon could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent., intplcnonplink: https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-56.pdf, plcnofilbool: 0, plcnofiltext: Landlords in Oregon could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons other than nonpayment of rent., intplcnofillink: https://www.oregon.gov/gov/Documents/executive_orders/eo_20-56.pdf, plccaresbool: 0, plccarestext: Courts in Oregon did not require landlords to certify that the dwelling is not subject to the CARES Act federal eviction moratorium when filing to evict a tenant., intcareslink: No relevant order, plctldbool: 0, plctldtext: Court deadlines in Oregon were not tolled., intplctldlink: https://www.courts.oregon.gov/rules/Documents/CJO-20-006-AmendedOrderImposingLevel3RestrictionsCourtOperations.pdf, plcnohearbool: 0, plcnoheartext: Eviction hearings were not blocked throughout the full duration of the moratorium., plcnonewbool: 0, plcnonewtext: Eviction orders were not stayed in Oregon. , plcsealbool: 0, plcsealtext: Eviction records are not automatically sealed in Oregon.
