Additional rental assistance was made available after parts of this moratorium ended., intdebtlink: https://www.oregonrentalassistance.org/, plccgbool: 0, plccgtext: Oregon did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/16/20, the OR Supreme Court issued an order that required all courts to, effective 03/19/20, continue hearings in forcible entry and detainer proceedings until 03/27; this order was then extended 03/27/20 and 05/15/20, when the high court stated that trials in FED matters would not take place until after 07/01 and allowed filings. On 03/22/20, Gov. Brown issued an order prohibiting enforcement of evictions for non-payment of rent for 90 days [06/20/20]. On 04/01/20, Gov. Brown issued an order prohibiting termination of a tenancy for non-payment of rent through notice, filing, for 90 days [06/30/20]. On 06/24/20, the OR legislature passed a bill that prohibited a landlord from initiating or continuing an action to take possession of a dwelling unit based on nonpayment of rent until 09/30/20. After the emergency period, a tenant has a 6 month grace period that ends on 3/31/21 to pay balance. On 10/01/20, Gov. Brown issued an order instating a moratorium on notice, filing or continuation of an eviction action for non-payment. The order extends the year of occupancy until after the moratorium ends. On 12/17/20, the Governor affirmed that the 10/01 order would extend through 12/31/20, as confirmed by the Governor's General Counsel.  On 12/23/20, the Oregon legislature passed a bill extending a moratorium on notice and filing until 06/30/21 for those tenants who provided a declaration of COVID hardship to their landlords until 06/30/21. On 5/20/21, the legislature passed a bill, effective 07/01/21, extending the moratorium on notice and filing to 02/28/22. The same legislation also prohibited landlords from charging late fees on rent that comes due during that period; prohibited landlords from reporting deliquent balances that accrued during this period to credit agencies; and gave tenants a grace period to pay accrued rent at any time until 02/28/21.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Oregon could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Oregon could not file to evict tenants who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Oregon could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Oregon could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons other than nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Oregon did not require landlords to certify that the dwelling is not subject to the CARES Act federal eviction moratorium when filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Oregon were not tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings were not blocked throughout the full duration of the moratorium.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Oregon.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction records are not automatically sealed in Oregon. Oregon courts will grant a motion to seal the eviction case record if the tenant complies with stipulation agreement or if judgment was given in tenant's favor, among other reasons.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Oregon could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Oregon could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Oregon could still enforce non-emergency eviction orders, except for those relating to nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Oregon did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Neither Oregon's governor nor the Public Utility Commission issued an order requiring utilities to suspend service shutoffs during the pandemic. Many utilities have voluntarily suspended disconnections.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Oregon's governor and Public Utility Commission did not take action to require utilities to suspend service shutoffs during the pandemic.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Legislation in Oregon granted tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrued between April 1, 2020 and April 30, 2021.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Oregon were prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Foreclosure proceedings in Oregon were paused.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Oregon could not charge late fees during the moratorium.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Oregon did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Oregon made millions of dollars in new rental assistance funding available to renters struggling to pay rent during the pandemic. Additional rental assistance was made available after parts of this moratorium ended.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Oregon did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

content.$t: stname: Pennsylvania, intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 3,457,067, evstat2: 1,111,779, intstat3: 395,991, intstat4: 1,557,665, intstat5: 0, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 0, intstat7: 0, stars: 3.13, intinitiationscore: 0.8, intcourtscore: 0.7, intenfscore: 1, intsupportscore: 0.5, inttenscore: 0, sttext: On 03/18/20, the PA Supreme Court announced, effective as of the "close of business on 03/19/20," that the courts would close except for emergency matters, which did not include evictions, and that no state official should enforce an eviction while the order was in effect. On 04/01/20, the PA Supreme Court issued an order that extended its earlier order and clarified that "the intent of this provision is that, in view of the economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, during this timeframe no officer, official, or other person employed by the Pennsylvania Judiciary at any level shall effectuate an eviction, ejectment, or other displacement from a residence based upon the failure to make a monetary payment." On 04/28/20, after one further extensions, the high court announced that this moratorium was set to end on 05/11/20. On 05/07/20, Gov. Wolf announced that, effective 05/11/20, the statute requiring notice before filing for eviction would be suspended for 60 days until 7/10/20. On 05/21/20, the Governor issued an order that limited the moratorium to evictions for non-payment of rent or exceeding the lease. On 07/09/20, commencing 7/10/20, Gov. Wolfe extended this order until 08/31/20. In a section explaining the scope of the order, the Governor stated that "The provisions of this Order and the suspension of the Acts under this Order apply only to matters involving the nonpayment of monies as well as to those proceedings related to removal of any tenant solely because the tenant has held over or exceeded the term of a lease.", plcstandoutbool: 0, until: May 11, 2020, intwtxp: SC gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/18/20, the PA Supreme Court announced, effective as of the "close of business on 03/19/20," that the courts would close except for emergency matters, which did not include evictions, and that no state official should enforce an eviction while the order was in effect. On 04/01/20, the PA Supreme Court issued an order that extended its earlier order and clarified that "the intent of this provision is that, in view of the economic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, during this timeframe no officer, official, or other person employed by the Pennsylvania Judiciary at any level shall effectuate an eviction, ejectment, or other displacement from a residence based upon the failure to make a monetary payment." On 04/28/20, after one further extensions, the high court announced that this moratorium was set to end on 05/11/20. On 05/07/20, Gov. Wolf announced that, effective 05/11/20, the statute requiring notice before filing for eviction would be suspended for 60 days until 7/10/20. On 05/21/20, the Governor issued an order that limited the moratorium to evictions for non-payment of rent or exceeding the lease. On 07/09/20, commencing 7/10/20, Gov. Wolfe extended this order until 08/31/20. In a section explaining the scope of the order, the Governor stated that "The provisions of this Order and the suspension of the Acts under this Order apply only to matters involving the nonpayment of monies as well as to those proceedings related to removal of any tenant solely because the tenant has held over or exceeded the term of a lease."

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Pennsylvania could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Pennsylvania could not file to evict tenants who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Pennsylvania could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Pennsylvania could not file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in South Carolina required landlords to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant, when filings resumed on May 12, 2020.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Pennsylvania did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Pennsylvania's Public Utility Commission ordered that jursidictional utilities cannot disconnect electric, natural gas, water, wastewater, telecommunications, and steam service for reason of nonpayment.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in Pennsylvania were required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Pennsylvania did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Pennsylvania were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

content.$t: stname: Rhode Island, intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 365,613, evstat2: 96,630, intstat3: 34,344, intstat4: 163,320, intstat5: 0, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 0, intstat7: 0, stars: 1.98, intinitiationscore: 0.8, intcourtscore: 0.5, intenfscore: 0, intsupportscore: 0, inttenscore: 0, sttext: On 03/17/20, the RI Supreme Court issued an order continuing all non-essential proceedings through 04/17/20, which included evictions; eviction flings were not prohibited by this order. On 04/08/20, the high court extended the prohibition on non-essential proceedings and stated that filings in eviction cases would not be accepted through 5/17/20. On 05/15/20, the Supreme Court issued an order allowing eviction filings and hearings to resume after 06/01/20. gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/17/20, the RI Supreme Court issued an order continuing all non-essential proceedings through 04/17/20, which included evictions; eviction flings were not prohibited by this order. On 04/08/20, the high court extended the prohibition on non-essential proceedings and stated that filings in eviction cases would not be accepted through 5/17/20. On 05/15/20, the Supreme Court issued an order allowing eviction filings and hearings to resume after 06/01/20. On 05/22/20, the District Court set out a protocol for handling eviction cases, which provided that no cases filed after the pandemic began would be heard until after 07/01/20.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Rhode Island could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Rhode Island could not file to evict tenants who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Rhode Island could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Rhode Island could not file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Landlords in Rhode Island were not required to certify that a dwelling was not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant, however, eviction filings were not accepted during the state eviction moratorium.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Rhode Island were tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could not be held in Rhode Island during the moratorium.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Rhode Island.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Rhode Island.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Rhode Island could still enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Rhode Island could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Rhode Island could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Rhode Island did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Rhode Island's Public Utilities Commission directed all jurisdictional electric, gas, water, and wastewater utilities to suspend service disconnections for reason of nonpayment.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in Rhode Island were required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Rhode Island did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Rhode Island were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Rhode Island did not address foreclosures.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Rhode Island could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Rhode Island did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance wasn't available in Rhode Island during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, though it became available to Rhode Island renters later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Rhode Island did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/17/20, SC Supreme Court ordered that all "ordered and scheduled" evictions from 03/17/20-03/31/20 must be rescheduled to a date after 05/01/20. On 03/18/20, the high court expanded its order, requiring that courts not "accept applications for ejectment, schedule hearings, issue writs or warrants of ejectment, or proceed in any other manner regarding evictions" until further order. On 04/30/20, the Supreme Court announced that the combined moratoria issued on 03/17 and 03/18 would lift as of 05/15/20.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in South Carolina could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in South Carolina could not file to evict tenants who had experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in South Carolina could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in South Carolina could not file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in South Carolina required landlords to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant, when filings resumed on May 15, 2020.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines were no longer tolled in South Carolina.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could not be held in South Carolina.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were stayed in South Carolina.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in South Carolina.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in South Carolina could still enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in South Carolina could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in South Carolina could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in South Carolina did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: South Carolina's Public Service Commission ordered that while utilities may still disconnect service for residents who do not pay utility bills, the utilities must provide information about payment plans and payment assistant programs prior to disconnection.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: South Carolina's governor and Public Service Commission did not take action to require utilities to suspend service shutoffs during the pandemic.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in South Carolina did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in South Carolina were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Courts in South Carolina did not hear foreclosure cases during the moratorium.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in South Carolina could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in South Carolina did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance wasn't available in South Carolina during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, though it became available to South Carolina renters later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: South Carolina did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Tennessee did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Tennessee's Public Utility Commission ordered that jurisdictional natural gas, electric, water, and wastewater utilities suspend disconnection of service for nonpayment.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Tennessee's Public Utility Commission ordered that jurisdictional utilities reconnect service that was disconnected for lack of payment on or after March 12, 2020.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Tennessee did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Tennessee were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Tennessee did not directly address foreclosure cases.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Tennessee could charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Tennessee did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance wasn't available in Tennessee during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, though it became available to Tennessee renters later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Tennessee did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/19/20, the TX Supreme Court issued an order prohibiting proceedings in forcible entry and detainer cases until after 04/19 but allowed new cases to be filed. Courts were permitted to issue writs of possession, but such writs could not be executed until after 04/26. This order was extended on 04/06 and on 04/27. The 04/27/20 order extended the prohibition on proceedings until after 05/18 and on execution until after 05/27.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Texas could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Orders in Texas did not prevent landlords from filing to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Orders in Texas did not prevent landlords from filing to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Orders in Texas did not prevent landlords from filing to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Texas required landlords to certify that a dwelling is not subject to the CARES Act federal eviction moratorium before filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Texas were tolled until May 18th.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could not be held in Texas during the moratorium.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were stayed during the moratorium.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Texas.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Texas could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Texas could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Texas could not enforce eviction orders issued for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Texas did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: The Texas Public Utility Commission ordered jurisdictional utility companies not to shut off water or electricity to customers financially impacted by COVID-19.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: The order from the Texas Public Utility Commission did not clarify if utility providers in Texas were required to restore service for free to residents whose utilities were shut off before the crisis started.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Current orders in Texas did not provide a grace period for tenants to pay past-due rent.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Texas were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Texas did not address foreclosures.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Texas could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Texas did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance wasn't available in Texas during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, though it became available to Texas renters later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Texas did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 04/01/20, effective immediately, Gov. Herbert issued an order that suspended eviction enforcement where the tenant was current on rent payments as of 3/31/20 and had 1) suffered job loss or lost income because of COVID-19, 2) had been ordered to self-isolate, or 3) tested positive for COVID-19. On 04/02/20, Gov. Herbert issued another order which limited the 04/01 order; this order suspended eviction enforcement only where tenant was current on rent payments as of 3/31/20 and had suffered job loss or lost income because of COVID-19 (removes self-isolation and testing positive for COVID-19). Gov. Herbert's order was set to and did expire at 11:59 PM on May 15, 2020.

content.$t: stname: Vermont, intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 157,514, evstat2: 47,367, intstat3: 16,956, intstat4: 76,019, intstat5: 0, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 0, intstat7: 0, stars: 2.48, intinitiationscore: 0.2, intcourtscore: 0.6, intenfscore: 1, intsupportscore: 0.75, inttenscore: 0.5, sttext: On 03/16/20, the VT Supreme Court announced a suspension of all non-emergency Superior Court proceedings (eviction proceedings were not listed as emergency matters), effective 03/17/20. After two extensions, the high court stated on 05/13/20 that non-emergency hearings could resume as of 06/01/20. On 05/14/20, legislation was signed into law which provided that a landlord could not give notice of eviction for non-payment of rent. The legislation also provided that the court should automatically stay any existing writs filed after the legislation went into effect, and stay any pending orders of eviction or issued orders of eviction. Sheriffs are prohibited from serving civil process. The legislation remains in effect until "30 days after the Governor terminates the state of emergency by declaration." The state of emergency terminated on 06/15/21, so the legislation will remain in effect , plcstandoutbool: 1, until: June 30, 2021 (end of study period), intwtxp: Vermont_Executive Order_No. 01-20 gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/16/20, the VT Supreme Court announced a suspension of all non-emergency Superior Court proceedings (eviction proceedings were not listed as emergency matters), effective 03/17/20. After two extensions, the high court stated on 05/13/20 that non-emergency hearings could resume as of 06/01/20. On 05/14/20, legislation was signed into law which provided that a landlord could not give notice of eviction for non-payment of rent. The legislation also provided that the court should automatically stay any existing writs filed after the legislation went into effect, and stay any pending orders of eviction or issued orders of eviction. Sheriffs are prohibited from serving civil process. The legislation remains in effect until "30 days after the Governor terminates the state of emergency by declaration." The state of emergency terminated on 06/15/21, so the legislation will remain in effect

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Vermont could not begin eviction cases by serving a notice to quit to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Vermont could still file to evict tenants who experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Vermont could still file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Vermont could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Vermont required landlords to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines relating to eviction in Vermont were not tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Emergency legislation stayed new or pending eviction proceedings until the end of the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders in Vermont were stayed, and new orders could not be issued, for the duration of the state of emergency and thirty days thereafter.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Vermont.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Vermont could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Vermont could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Vermont could not remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: At the end of the COVID-19 Housing Policy Scorecard study period, the emergency measures in Vermont's eviction moratorium were scheduled to remain in effect for 30 days after the governor ended the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Jurisdictional utility companies could disconnect electric, natural gas, or telecommunications service for reasons of nonpayment, provided they comply with emergency rules passed by Vermont's Public Utilities Commission.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility providers in Vermont are required to restore service for free to residents whose utilities were shut off before the crisis started.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Vermont did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Vermont were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Vermont required courts to stay foreclosure cases until 30 days after the Governor declares an end to the state of emergency.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Vermont could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Vermont did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Renters in Vermont could apply for rental assistance during the eviction moratorium, including through the Vermont Emergency Rental Assistance Program (VERAP) at the end of the study period.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Vermont did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

content.$t: stname: Virginia, intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 2,646,746, evstat2: 447,214, intstat3: 239,299, intstat4: 1,057,536, intstat5: 1, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 2,646,746, intstat7: 1,057,536, stars: 0.78, intinitiationscore: 0, intcourtscore: 0.7, intenfscore: 0, intsupportscore: 0.5, inttenscore: 0, sttext: On 03/16/20, the VA Supreme Court issued an order closing the courts to non-emergency, non-essential proccedings for 21 days. This order did not specifically prohibit evictions but they were not included in the list of essential proceedings. On 03/27/20 and again on 04/22/20, the high court extended the judicial emergency; these orders stated specifically that writs of eviction should be continued. On 05/06/20, the Supreme Court issued a new order, effective 05/18/20, that no longer stated that writs of eviction should be continued; this order was extended to 06/28/20 by order on 06/01/20. On 06/07/20, Gov. Northam requested that the Supreme Court again issue an eviction moratorium for 21 days. On 06/08/20, the Supreme Court issued an order prohibiting issuance of writs of evictions effective 06/08/20 and continuing through 06/28/20. That order expired without an extension. On 07/24/20, Gov. Northam again requested that the Supreme Court issue an eviction moratorium. gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/16/20, the VA Supreme Court issued an order closing the courts to non-emergency, non-essential proccedings for 21 days. This order did not specifically prohibit evictions but they were not included in the list of essential proceedings. On 03/27/20 and again on 04/22/20, the high court extended the judicial emergency; these orders stated specifically that writs of eviction should be continued. On 05/06/20, the Supreme Court issued a new order, effective 05/18/20, that no longer stated that writs of eviction should be continued; this order was extended to 06/28/20 by order on 06/01/20. On 06/07/20, Gov. Northam requested that the Supreme Court again issue an eviction moratorium for 21 days. On 06/08/20, the Supreme Court issued an order prohibiting issuance of writs of evictions effective 06/08/20 and continuing through 06/28/20. That order expired without an extension. On 07/24/20, Gov. Northam again requested that the Supreme Court issue an eviction moratorium. On 08/07/20, the Supreme Court issued an order prohibiting issuance of writs of eviction for failure to pay rent effective 08/10/20 through 09/07/20. On 11/18/2020, Gov. Northam signed a bill that provided that requires landlords who own more than four units to offer tenants payment plans if they fall behind on rent. If a tenant fails to pay rent (for owners with fewer than 4 units) or fails to pay on a payment plan (for owners with 4 or more units), the landlord must provide the tenant with notice of the availability of rent relief, and if the tenant cooperates in filing a rent relief application, the landlord cannot file for eviction for 45 days while the application is pending. However, if the application is not approved within 45 days, the landlord can proceed to evict the tenant.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Virginia could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Orders in Virginia did not prevent landlords from filing to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Virginia could file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Virginia could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Virginia did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Virginia were tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Courts in Virginia could not eviction hearings.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were stayed in Virginia.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Virginia.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Virginia could still enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Virginia could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Virginia could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Virginia did not not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: An order from Virginia's State Corporation Commission directed electric, natural gas, and water companies to suspend involuntary service disconnections during the pandemic.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in Virginia were required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Virginia did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Virginia were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: The Governor of Virginia ordered that housing providers work to avoid foreclosures during the moratorium.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Virginia can charge late fees only if those fees are provided for in a written agreement. Where allowed, late fees are capped at 10% of monthly rent or 10 % of the remaining balance owed by the tenant.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Virginia did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance wasn't available in Virginia during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, though it became available to West Virginia renters later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Virginia has not guaranteed legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

Landlords are prohibited from giving 20-day notice for holdovers unless necessary to health and saftey. On 04/16/20, the Governor removed the non-payment limitation. The order prohibits attempting to collect through a collection agency any unpaid rent unless a property manager demonstrates by a preponderance of the evidence that the tenant refused a payment plan. On 06/02/20, Gov. On 12/31/20, Gov. Inslee extended the moratorium through 03/31/21. gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/18/20, Gov. Inslee issued an order prohibiting giving of notice, filing for or enforcement of an eviction for non-payment of rent. Landlords are prohibited from giving 20-day notice for holdovers unless necessary to health and saftey. On 04/16/20, the Governor removed the non-payment limitation. The order prohibits attempting to collect through a collection agency any unpaid rent unless a property manager demonstrates by a preponderance of the evidence that the tenant refused a payment plan. On 06/02/20, Gov. Inslee added a further prohibition on retaliation for exercising rights under order and added an exception where the landlord gave 60 days notice of their intent to sell the property or occupy it as a residence. On 12/31/20, Gov. Inslee extended the moratorium through 03/31/21. On 03/18/21, the Gov. extended the moratorium through 06/30/21.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Washington could not issue notices of eviction to tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Washington could not file to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Washington could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Washington could not file to evict tenants, except for emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Washington did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant, however, courts were not accepting any non-emergency eviction filings during the moratorium.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Washington were not tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Courts in Washington were not explicitly ordered not to hold eviction hearings, though it is unlikely that non-emergnecy hearings were held as eviction filings were prohibited.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders in Washington were not stayed.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Washington.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Washington could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Washington could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Washington could not enforce eviction orders issued for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Washington did not not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Utilities service providers in Washington could not disconnect service for nonpayment.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Utility providers in Washington were required to restore service previously disconnected for nonpayment without charge.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Washington did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Orders in Washington instruct that landlords may not report to credit agencies where nonpayment was related to COVID-19 unless they certify that a tenant has been offered and refused/failed to comply with a repayment plan.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Washington did not address foreclosures.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Washington could not charge late fees for nonpayment occurring after February 29, 2020.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Landlords in Washington could not increase rent until the end of the moratorium declared by the Governor.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Washington allocated hundreds of millions of dollars in federal funding for rental assistance, including through the Eviction Rent Assistance Program (ERAP) and Treasury Rent Assistance Program (T-RAP) programs. Rental assistance was distributed by local organizations, so it was not available in all parts of the state at the same time.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: In April 2021, the right to counsel in eviction cases was signed into law in Washington.

gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/22/20, the WV Supreme Court of Appeals announced a judicial emergency that suspended all proceedings, deadlines, and statutes of limitations from 03/23/20 through 04/10/20.  The judicial emergency was extended on 04/03 [until 05/01/20] and on 04/22 through 05/15/20. In its 04/22/20 order, the high court stated that wrongful occupation and eviction proceedings could not be held prior to 05/18/20.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in West Virginia could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Orders in West Virginia did not prevent landlords from filing to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in West Virginia could still file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in West Virginia could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in West Virginia did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in West Virginia were tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could not be held in West Virginia during the eviction moratorium.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in West Virginia.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in West Virginia.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in West Virginia could still enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in West Virginia could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in West Virginia could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in West Virginia did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Neither West Virginia's governor nor the Public Service Commission issued an order requiring utilities to suspend service shutoffs during the pandemic. The chairman of West Virginia's utilities commission informally requested that utilities suspend disconnections.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: West Virginia's governor and Public Service Commission did not take binding action to require utilities to suspend service shutoffs during the pandemic.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in West Virginia did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in West Virginia were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Courts in West Virginia did not hear foreclosure cases during the moratorium.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in West Virginia could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in West Virginia did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance wasn't available in West Virginia during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, though it became available to West Virginia renters later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: West Virginia did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

Evers issued an order that prohibited landlords giving notice of eviction to a tenant for failure to pay rent; commencing (filing) an eviction for non-payment of rent; or delivering to a sheriff a writ of execution arising from a failure to pay rent without showing of imminent threat to serious physical harm to another person. Any commencement or delivery of writ to sheriff must be accompanied by an affiddavit attesting that the failure to proceed with eviction will result in imminent threat of serious physical harm to another person. Sheriffs were also prohibited from enforcing writs of execution arising from a failure to pay rent. gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/27/20, effective immediately, Gov. Evers issued an order that prohibited landlords giving notice of eviction to a tenant for failure to pay rent; commencing (filing) an eviction for non-payment of rent; or delivering to a sheriff a writ of execution arising from a failure to pay rent without showing of imminent threat to serious physical harm to another person. Any commencement or delivery of writ to sheriff must be accompanied by an affiddavit attesting that the failure to proceed with eviction will result in imminent threat of serious physical harm to another person. Sheriffs were also prohibited from enforcing writs of execution arising from a failure to pay rent. The Governor's order was set to and did expire 60 days from issuance [05/26/20].

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Notices of eviction could not be issued to tenants in Wisconsin.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Wisconsin could not file to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Wisconsin could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Wisconsin could not file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Wisconsin did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not covered by the CARES Act eviction moratorium prior to filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$intcareslink.$t: WI_SupremeCourt_Decision_060520 [Rejecting emergency request for a temporary rule]

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Wisconsin were not tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Orders in Wisconsin did not prevent eviction cases from being heard.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Wisconsin.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Wisconsin. However, if an eviction action was denied or dismissed, it is removed from public display every two years.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Wisconsin could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Wisconsin could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the moratorium.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Wisconsin could not enforce eviction orders issued for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Wisconsin did not extend protections beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Utility providers in Wisconsin could not shut off water, electric, and natural gas utilities. Some internet providers are giving free or low-cost access.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Wisconsin's Public Service Commission required water, electric, and natural gas utiities must make reasonable attempts to reconnect service to an occupied unit that has been disconnected.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Wisconsin did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Wisconsin were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Foreclosure proceedings could not be begun in Wisconsin during the moratorium.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Wisconsin could charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Wisconsin did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Rental assistance wasn't available in Wisconsin during their 2020 state level eviction moratorium, though it became available to Wisconsin renters later in the pandemic.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Wisconsin did not guarantee legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

gsx$sttext.$t: Wyoming did not implement any statewide eviction moratorium during the pandemic. Rental assistance was available to renters in Wyoming at some points during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Wyoming could still give notice of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Orders in Wyoming did not prevent landlords from filing to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Wyoming could file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Wyoming could still file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Wyoming did not require landlords to certify that a dwelling is not subject to the CARES Act federal eviction moratorium when filing to evict a tenant.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: Court deadlines in Wyoming were not tolled.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Eviction hearings could still be held in Wyoming.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were not stayed in Wyoming.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records were not sealed in Wyoming.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Wyoming could still enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Wyoming could still enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Wyoming could still remove tenants from homes to enforce non-emergency eviction orders.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Orders in Wyoming did not extend past the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Neither Wyoming's governor nor the Public Service Commission issued an order requiring utilities to suspend service shutoffs during the pandemic. The Public Service Commission authorized utilities to suspend disconnections, but did not ordere this.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Wyoming's governor and Public Service Commission did not take action to require utilities to suspend service shutoffs during the pandemic.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Orders in Wyoming did not give tenants a grace period to pay rental debt that accrues during the pandemic.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Wyoming were not prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Orders in Wyoming did not address foreclosures.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Wyoming could still charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Orders in Wyoming did not prohibit landlords from raising rent when renewing leases during the pandemic.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Wyoming did not institute an eviction moratorium at any point during the study period. Rental assistance, including from the federal government, was available at some points during the study period.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Wyoming has not guaranteed legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.

content.$t: stname: Washington, D.C., intlstupdt: 06/30/21, evstat1: 359,585, evstat2: 49,811, intstat3: 42,907, intstat4: 163,751, intstat5: 0, intstat55: 0, intstat6: 0, intstat7: 0, stars: 4.63, intinitiationscore: 1, intcourtscore: 1, intenfscore: 1, intsupportscore: 0.75, inttenscore: 0.75, sttext: On 03/15/20, the D.C Superior Court stayed all eviction proceedings.  On 03/17/20, the D.C. Council passed legislation that extended the period between service of a summons and an eviction trial to include the duration of the public health emergency, effectively halting any pending eviction proceedings. The legislation also prohibited execution of evictions during the public health emergency. On 05/13/20, the D.C. Council passed legislation that prohibited the filing of an eviction complaint for the duration of the public health emergency and 60 days thereafter. On 05/14/20, the D.C. Superior Court amended its earlier order and provided that "All evictions, foreclosure proceedings, and debt collection proceedings are stayed to the extent required by statute." On 10/23/20, effective 12/23/20, the D.C. Council passed legislation that prohibited landlords from giving notice to tenants for the duration of the public health emergency and 60 days thereafter. On 12/16/20, a D.C. Superior Court judge struck down the filing ban as an unconstitutional restriction of the right of property owners to access the courts. On 02/02/21, the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia issued an order staying the D.C. Superior Court Order, pending the decision of the D.C. Superior Court on the merits of the appeal. On 02/19/21, the stay was ended by order of the D.C. Superior Court. On 05/13/21, the D.C. Court of Appeals stayed the D.C. gsx$sttext.$t: On 03/15/20, the D.C Superior Court stayed all eviction proceedings.  On 03/17/20, the D.C. Council passed legislation that extended the period between service of a summons and an eviction trial to include the duration of the public health emergency, effectively halting any pending eviction proceedings. The legislation also prohibited execution of evictions during the public health emergency. On 05/13/20, the D.C. Council passed legislation that prohibited the filing of an eviction complaint for the duration of the public health emergency and 60 days thereafter. On 05/14/20, the D.C. Superior Court amended its earlier order and provided that "All evictions, foreclosure proceedings, and debt collection proceedings are stayed to the extent required by statute." On 10/23/20, effective 12/23/20, the D.C. Council passed legislation that prohibited landlords from giving notice to tenants for the duration of the public health emergency and 60 days thereafter. On 12/16/20, a D.C. Superior Court judge struck down the filing ban as an unconstitutional restriction of the right of property owners to access the courts. On 02/02/21, the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia issued an order staying the D.C. Superior Court Order, pending the decision of the D.C. Superior Court on the merits of the appeal. On 02/19/21, the stay was ended by order of the D.C. Superior Court. On 05/13/21, the D.C. Court of Appeals stayed the D.C. Superior Court's order.

gsx$plcnoticetext.$t: Landlords in Washington, D.C. could not give notices of eviction to tenants.

gsx$plccofiltext.$t: Landlords in Washington, D.C. could not file to evict tenants who have experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcnonptext.$t: Landlords in Washington, D.C. could not file to evict tenants for nonpayment of rent.

gsx$plcnofiltext.$t: Landlords in Washington, D.C. could not file to evict tenants for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plccarestext.$t: Courts in Washington, D.C. did not require landlords to certify that a home is not covered by the federal CARES Act eviction moratorium before filing to evict a tenant, however, eviction filings are not currently accepted in Washington, D.C.

gsx$plctldtext.$t: All tenant deadlines in Washington, D.C. were tolled during the public health emergency.

gsx$plcnoheartext.$t: Only emergency eviction cases were heard in Washington, D.C. during the eviction moratorium.

gsx$plcnonewtext.$t: Eviction orders were stayed in Washington, D.C.

gsx$plcsealtext.$t: Eviction case records are sealed in Washington, D.C. 30 days (if the tenant prevails) or 3 years (if the landlord prevails) after the hearing. Tenants can also motion to have cases sealed earlier in certain circumstances.

gsx$plccovenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Washington, D.C. could not enforce an order to remove a tenant who has experienced financial hardship due to the pandemic.

gsx$plcpayenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Washington, D.C. could not enforce an order of eviction for nonpayment of rent during the moratorium.

gsx$plcnoenftext.$t: Law enforcement in Washington, D.C. could not enforce eviction orders issued for non-emergency reasons.

gsx$plcextmortext.$t: Emergency legislation in Washington, D.C. extended the prohibition on eviction filings 30 days beyond the state of emergency.

gsx$plcnoshtext.$t: Utility providers in Washington, D.C. could not shut off water, natural gas, or electricity because of nonpayment during a public health emergency.

gsx$plcfrrctext.$t: Orders did not make it clear if utility companies in Washington, D.C. were required to reconnect already-suspended service without a fee. However, recent legislation created a fund to the pay water bill balance for low-income residents.

gsx$plcarstext.$t: Emergency legislation in Washington, D.C. required property owners to provide a rent payment plan program for tenants in buildings with five or more units. Orders did not give a grace period or extend mandatory payment plans for tenants in smaller buildings.

gsx$plcnoreptext.$t: Landlords in Washington, D.C. were prohibited from reporting missed or late rent payments to credit agencies where tenants have entered into a payment plan. Consumer reporting agencies are required to add a COVID-19 alert to a file if a person experienced COVID-19 hardship and users of the report are prohibited from acting on information in the report during the time of COVID-19 hardship.

gsx$plcnofctext.$t: Emergency legislation in Washington, D.C. prohibited the initiation and conducting of foreclosures during a public health emergency.

gsx$plclatftext.$t: Landlords in Washington, D.C. could not charge late fees.

gsx$plcraisetext.$t: Any rent increase in Washington, D.C. is null and void if the effective date on the notice of rent increase occurs during and 30 days after the period of emergency, and if the notice was provided to the tenant prior to, but takes effect following, the public health emergency.

gsx$plcdebttext.$t: Renters in Washington, D.C. could apply for rental assistance during the eviction moratorium, including through STAY DC at the end of the study period.

gsx$plccgtext.$t: Washington, D.C. has not guaranteed legal counsel to tenants who face eviction.
